Description:
I'm sorry about this post. It's gonna be a whole lot of hand wringing and mental masturbation. But I never seem to be able to process this in a meaningful way - and it makes attending NA and AA meetings a real pain. I don't seem to have the same kind of sickness that everyone else is describing - I'm having trouble relating to anyone at all there. I don't know what it's like for normal functional people, nor do I know what it's like for people who taste 1% beer and come to next month in jail after charging a rhino to a military convoy dressed in wehrmact univorm. Instead of this all-encompassing disease people speak of in groups it's like a slight poly-addiction as parts of the maladaptive patterns I've learned due to ADHD - and the cravings themselves are way lessened due to starting on strattera.

At the same time I've now, for the upteenth time, decided to be sober after binge-drinking all of my money away once again - BUT I can ween off unaided and I did not really need to do all that, there were factors in play. On a scale from one to then how much addict's horseshit was condenced in that last paragraph in your opinion? I'm self aware to a point, but my problem is it never seems to be enough. I will go on groups and feel like an impostor the whole time, go home feeling miserable and alone, and eventually relapse. This time I actually want it to stick, I am indepted, uneducated tool who just turned 27 - and it seems like I need to get my life in order now.

Been getting super high off high amounts of thc edibles and stuff every single day. I started off only doing it weekends but I just kept doing it. Today would be my first day not getting high?cause I started popping random pills, and yesterday I drank a bottle of cough syrup just to get High. It?s like I crave being high. And I just feel so annoyed and I don?t really care what others think of me?I?m tired of the bs. Irritation fume

My brothers been shooting heroin/meth for the past 5 years, ran away to cali 3 years ago. My childhood best friend overdosed on fentanyl in October. My dad who has been on meth for as long as I can remember finally got clean in January because he got covid and basically detoxed. I?ve always been a social drinker but lately I?ve been drinking around 2 bottles of wine a night. I feel like I?m drowning & and the only way I?m happy is when I?m buzzed even though I know what road I?m heading down. My family?s health declined severely through my brothers addiction on top of my dads own drug problems. My grandma had a stroke in November and my mom has become her primary caretaker. Im in graduate school right now & trying to help as much as I can, but I?m angry that my brother left me to do this on my own. On top of that, I feel guilty for being angry. I don?t even know if this post belongs here, pls delete if not.

I rlly need an opinion cuz idk bout this stuff i don?t rlly drugs. Idk if this is normal and im just overreacting but his drug habits does make me worried. I knew he drank and smoked weed here and there like every teen/YA but i never blinked an eye.

My bf gets defensive when i ask why he does what he does. I mean he said he quit vapes so i thought nun of his habits until he told me the stuff he does. Like he told me he has drank alcohol and drove so i told him to stop (he told me he?ll try not to but no promise. & it?s ok to do a little cuz he has a high tolerance). I know he did Oxy & percs but i thought he was jokin cuz he told me took an Oxy then when i said huh he said he jokin but he didn?t seem high so yk i brushed it off but we were otp.

He did shrooms recently and had a bad trip he told me after it happen tho i didn?t have any clue he even doing it?! He also told me he called his close friends but he didn?t tell/call me which hurt me on top of the fact he said he only told me cuz i asked not bc he wanted to. He planned to do tabs saturday with names he never said to me before but that plan fell thru.

Ik he did a favor for his plug and got drugs on sunday cuz he told me & i checked his location he was out but idk what his plug sells.

On the same day later we got into a spat when he told me he was smoking and stuff with his friends and i told him how i felt concerned. He said to me over text & i quote directly from text

?i have right to be secretive for my privacy and for my security.?

?i was doing drugs before i met u and will be doing drugs forever. i was depressed about shit before i met u and will continue to be until some shit in my life gets better.?

?ik what drugs can do to me and i am smart enough to not get in positions where drugs can hurt me?

idk what to think anymore like ik he?s depressed and stuff and i try to be there for him. I mean i don?t think he?s ever been high around me but maybe that?s cause he knows i get upset or maybe i?m to naive to notice cuz i don?t notice when ppl are. Like I mean is this like a red flag or am i just overreacting??????

Also he does have a family history of substance abuse.

TL:DR my bf drinks , smokes weed , has done precs & oxy , and has done shrooms. (I think he only drinks at parties and he does smoke a bit but idk how often does it on a givin week & have no clue how often he does pills.) And gets defensive bout his drug use when i bring it up. Does he have a problem?

Ive smoked weed since 8th grade in middle school and have been hooked since. Im proud to say I haven?t smoked in over 10 days (cant remember last hit) and honestly I don?t wanna remember my last hit because I want it out of my life forever. Ever since I?ve smoked I?ve been (Lazy, unproductive, negative, sleeping issues, and digestion problems) I finally plan on going to trucking school and passing drug tests when I get my CDL so I can finally have a good future! I encourage anyone else to quit smoking and move on!

I'm a journalism student in Ontario, Canada. I am exploring harm reduction amidst the opioid crisis, and am currenlty working on a story on the importance of peer-assisted injection services at safe injection sites across the country. I am looking to speak with people who have experience with peer-assisted injection -- any and all experiences are welcome. Feel free to PM me with questions and I will answer them. Judgement-free, respectful zone. Thanks in advance. :)

don?t care how much I post on this I just don?t have anyone to talk too. As someone who suffers from depression and anxiety I feel like it?s coming all back even though I?m on antidepressants. I?ve also been getting high everyday, but I have nothing today?wel I could do cough syrup but I don?t know yet. I?m having such a shitty day and nothing even happen it?s all me feeling like shit. I literally am being a bitch. I just told one of my friends that their friend that died was a dumbass. Now I feel like a jackass. And I?ve been being a bitch all day. Just giving people dirty looks, being rude in general. I feel upset. I hate myself again

I'm not one to really seek out support for my problems, so this is really weird for me, and I don't even know if this is the right group I just need to know someone else in the world knows what I'm going through right now. A year ago I used to wake up, take 750 mg of phenibut and 2 g's of kratom. I'd chase them down with a few beers and smoke some weed. After I got a good buzz going I'd take some oxy and klonopin, chase down with more beer. Right before it was time to work do a couple lines of coke then pop my happy ass into work. That was my daily schedule for almost a year, up until last year I decided to quit, because I got an amazing girlfriend, who I saw myself spending the rest of my life with. We started living together, things were going good, then 8 months in she started talking to and flirting with another guy, doing who knows what else behind my back, saying I changed, and I'm not the same person I was when we started dating. Now I'm having a really shitty crisis where I'm feeling like the drugs made me who I was, made me into somebody who people liked, and I'm having serious thoughts of going back. I don't want to go back but life feels so empty now and I just want to feel normal again. I just wanted to get that out there into the open world of the internet.

I really want and need to find a support system to finally get clean... My DOC is meth and im 3 months clean off fent laced heroin. I could only get clean from H by starting the suboxone program in my town. it saved my life and is a miracle. they knew i still used meth but made a deal to get me off within a couple months once im stable off heroin.

well... there amazing people and so kind theyre giving me so much slack. But i was supposed to piss clean tomorrow and i relapsed 2 days ago after 4 days sober (the longest ive had in a year). i let them know imediatly and the response wasnt great obviously. If i cant pee clean in 1 week theyll most likely kick me out. meaning suboxone withdrawals and inevitable relapse on heroin. im not near ready and havent done much work on the route casue of my use. Even those 4 days felt great for my body though. and when i relapsed ive felt disgusting ever since. this stuff is pure poison

I?ve been doing a lot of Xanax and Valium lately like a lot and I can?t stop? I?m also on a shit ton of opiates a lot and smoke weed basicly 24/7. I?ve been on this shit for a long time and I really wanna stop but I can?t no matter how hard I try? my brother died from herion and you?d think that would be enough to scare me off of drugs forever but no it jus made me do them more cuz I want to escape. I?m only 16 and I?ve overdosed 2 times. I wanna have a good life but I can?t seem to leave the drugs behind.

What started with alcohol, has been a decade of one substance after the other. I need this for energy, or I need this for depression. My kids have seen me measure my kratom and phenibut for years and I always said it was for energy or a supplement for my protein shakes. Oooooooookay.

On substances im not an introvert anymore, im not shy and insecure and anxious. Im outgoing and talkative and creative. All of these things that make me an even better mother (I tell myself) because I've never been clean longer than a couple weeks off of EVERYTHING for 8 years to even know.

I remember my creativity when my kids were 1,2,3...

I know I don't need drugs to be that person. But I can never make it through withdrawal/ paws and be a good enough mother, so I go back or I find another "legal" drug. (No I have 0 help to go to treatment. None.) I've been "sick" SO MANY TIMES for a week or 2 on end when they've had to basically fend for themselves. That can't happen again. Ever.

This last habit cost me $20k. I panic about paying lunch money at their school but I can go pay $50 a pop for "energy and motivation"?!?

As I popped my last handful of pills which I thought was discreet, my 8 year old in the backseat of the car coloring... "mommy why are you taking so many pills? You don't need those mommy." She's right.

I stopped drinking a 5th of vodka a day 5 or so years ago after I had to drink(unknowingly, or so I THOUGHT!) To be social at my kids sports game. Drove home trashed, they called the only person they knew hysterical trying to give them directions of where we were. Police came because I was in someone's front lawn - I fought them and three other people infront of my kids - woke up the next morning in my bed clueless.

I could have lost them all. Just like that. They all remember that. My 8 year old doesn't even like me to drink wine or beer, tells me I don't need it. She knows I act differently, even though in my mind I need it to get things done etc.

I could be such a better mother. 50 hour work weeks, 3 kids, school, sports, home - HOW do I convince myself I can be amazing without all of this shit thats probably killing me?! I tell myself everyday & I already know I dont need this shit and I need to stop for my kids - but its like I HAVE to always be on SOMETHING?!

Title is pretty self explanatory. I only discovered a few hours ago, been sworn to secrecy by my mother. He?s been on it for the past 2 years and I didn?t even fucking notice the difference, I feel awful for not realising but I feel like I don?t even know him anymore. From what my mother has told me, he?s been clean for a few days and is staying home, he wants to try get clean at home before committing to something like rehab (I don?t know how this all works I?m sorry). I want to help him, spend time with him but every time i even look at him I can?t help but burst into tears. I don?t want to somehow turn him into a villain in my eyes because I know he isn?t, I love my Father so much and I want to do everything I possibly can for him, but i seriously don?t know what to do.

I?m sorry if it sounds like i?m completely rambling but i need advice on how to help my father please.

I?ve had the prescription for about 4 years, but for the past year I started gradually taking more and more. I?m able to get away with it for the time being because I can have it prescribed by my therapist and also my doctor. Usually I think at least in my country it would raise a red flag since i go through the pills about 5 times faster than if I were taking them as prescribed.

My misuse has also not gone unnoticed. My parents think I am doing drugs and they are not wrong but they don?t know it?s a prescription. Anyway what?s the difference if it?s legal or not? Coworkers also comment that I look like I live a hard life and that?s true because I barely sleep. For the past 5 months or so I am going to work with about 2-4 hours of sleep each night.

If it weren?t for old photos I was looking at today I would by even notice the change. Anyways as of tomorrow I am going to try and take them as prescribed or at least start to take less

I don't know how to talk around it so I'll just say it, I'm a sex addict, I've been holding off on any impulse for three weeks plus a day it's going pretty well, and I've got nobody but my girlfriend to thank for that. Well, she's been getting a bit more intimate lately, and you could cut the tension between us with a knife, and I'm honestly not sure if I should go for it

It's a nice and intimate moment between two people who have a decent trust between them, but everytime my mind wanders towards the subject of sex, I only think of it in the vein of "aw, nice, I'm gonna get a fix", and I feel liks that isn't the right way to go into it

I'd say it's like a food addiction, you're eating healthy, but then your best friend gets a promotion and the celebration calls for a pizza party. It wouldn't hurt to indulge, but it could be a gateway back to the problem

So I decided to tamper with a-pihp several weeks ago. It went rather disastrous but I was able to get my footing back on the right track. Fast forward a month of 2 and I decided I would try a-php to see what the hype was all about.

Now I?m going into day 3 and haven?t been able to fully put it away. I have some benzos for the comedown (almost make it even more enjoyable) but I have about a gram of php and 2 grams of apihp.

I'm so utterly screwed. The problem is that I don't want to get better, because I just enjoy Netflix so much (in a very guilt ridden way.) Everything else seems so boring in comparison to Netflix shows. Core areas of my life such as my sleep and work are suffering because of this very severe addiction. I think I'm more addicted to Netflix then I could possibly be to any drug. I just sit there clicking next episode over and over again and 6 hours go by. And I hate myself for it. Every night I say I'm going to stop, every time I go out of the house I say I'm going to stop, and then I come back inside and watch the show.

i didn?t realize mrn numbers allow other docs pharmacies and physicians to see diagnosis. i work in a sector and will be absolutely scrutinized or denied employment in pre physical exams if this pops up. because rehab brainwashed me that i was an addict and alcoholic (i ran aa instead of na) i told them i was an alcoholic and they wrote it down despite not asking about my drinking history. they just relied on my self diagnosis and didn?t ask much about how much i used only the length of time. i told them i was addicted to ambien and xanax which actually wasn?t true. i was dependent on them, and only abused them aka not take them as prescribed when i tried to get clean and use these as comfort meds getting off fentanyl which was a different beast. i was never an irresponsible drinker or a heavy one as i hated hangovers and thought it was a shitty drug overall.

many might disagree but my honest past drug resume is i never fall into addiction with any other substance except oxycodone.

when i had almost a year sober a small relapse of sniffing .5 mg of xanax i found in my room sent me to hating myself for screwing up, in reality this unhealthy view of my self and dishonest brainwashing by rehab set me up to fail if i used any substance, i guess it?s why it?s such a profitable business.

case point i never got opiates from the doc and self medicated after a traumatic car accident. i was given ambien and xanax which i used responsibly for almost two years and was tapered off no problem. it became an issue once opiates came into play and a poly substance depdence formed, and i was battling my opiate wd by abusing those meds and also becoming dependent but not addicted to them if that makes sense. only oxycodone i truley believe is my addiction.

id much rather not deal with the stigmatization, pain in the ass judgement and explanations in the future having ?sedative use disorder, hypnotic drug use disorder and opiate use disorder on my medical record. this sets me up for failure for pre employment physicals, or a situation where i have an accident at work and they have accesss to my records because i work in this sector. is it possible to remove this info i disclosed? at my rehab after all was said to 100% truth i only had been diagnosed as a opiate addict, not a poly substance addict like how i came off across. i didn?t realize doctors were so miseducated on addiction and told them i suffer from alcoholism and they listed that as on my record as well when i was always a responsible drinker. is there any way for them to erase the info i disclosed or remove the diagnosis ? id much rather lost allergic to opiates then have these diagnosis on my record for how annoying it makes to see doctors

I got addicted to Monster and Nos about two years ago when I worked the night shift for FedEx ground because it would keep me awake and able to push through loading so much shit all the time. I quit working there after a year but I've continued on drinking 2 or 3 cans a day sometimes 4 when I'm depressed. Every time I try to quit I get extremely painful headaches and a raw sensation in my gut that quickly goes away when I start drinking again. I've tried tapering off but when I drink even one I get immense cravings for another and the cycle continues. I can feel my health declining and my teeth feel weaker and weaker every day. Was wondering if anybody has had experience with this and could offer a non-typical solution that actually works.

I am an RN on an acute drug detox unit and am asking for input from others that have detoxed inpatient before. What would you qualify as a good detox nurse? What qualities would they have? What could I do as a nurse to make you more comfortable? I am also trying to think of things I can bring in for my patients to do on their downtime, when groups aren?t happening. So open to those suggestions as well. I love my patients and want them all to succeed and want to be there for them 1000%.

Age 39, smoker of 24 years. I have quit for months and years along the way. I have always had a massive association between alcohol and cigarettes. My undoing for smoking is ALWAYS when I get drunk, cos a)the mental association with alcohol just amplifies the craving b)the wall of self-discipline is weakened by alcohol and c)I'm surrounded by smokers offering me one. I haven't had a drink for 6 weeks nor any nicotine for 5 days, but I'm going to a function this weekend. I can totally see myself getting drunk and smoking AGAIN. Any helpful strategies?

Before I start I just want to say there is no offense to the ones in the twelve step program, AA, or decide to do abstinence. I do think moderation is possible for people like me who have been diagnosed with AUD. I tried everything and none of it worked. I think the ideal of full on abstinence for the rest of my life and starting all over to day 1 stressed me out. I've managed to successfully drink once a week or every two weeks I'll go and drink. Yes I do binge drink when I do, but I was thinking about trying naltrexone when I do. I've been doing this for a year a now and it helps me stay sober. I'm tired of feeling guilt about it though because I don't want to get judged by peers. Has this moderation thing worked for anyone for long periods or not? Please tell me your experiences.

Just got accepted into rehab for 5 months, calling out 2 anyone who has successfully went down this path and is in healthy recovery for tips and advice I'm cross addicted Alcohol/drugs (Heroin) I did a 28 day programme last year for the 1st time and it went well, the recovery afterwards not so well Any tips for the 5 months and recovery after would b very appreciated

It seems like im addicted to everything. Like I trade habits for new ones or that I circle back to old habits when the new ones cycle out. I date women who treat me like shit. When it finally breaks me, I trade that in for drugs, when I quit drugs, I move onto food, then back to a relationship, then to alcohol. Sometimes the addictions overlap. But idk where to go. Addiction counseling here is a joke. There are no peer support counseling groups. Im an opportunist addict.

Is there a test out there that can be used for a person that is trying to stop smoking, but is utilizing nicotine aids like patches, gum, lozenges, or whatever else is out there? So I'd imagine it would be testing for something other than nicotine since it would need to differentiate the aids from tobacco smoke.

I tried searching and couldn't find anything....hoping someone has some experience and can give me a quick and definitive answer.

I?m 23. I have dealt with sexual abuse and cheating for many years. I didn?t really rely on substances to help me get past any of it. I tried to kill myself and when I was discovered, my parents helped me go to therapy. Discovered I have clinical depression, anxiety, and OCD. My first experience with sexual assault was the trigger for all my borderline mental issues to come to their full glory. This all happened when I was 14 and I had kind of started becoming better around 19. I just smoked cigarettes first. But then I went to postgrad at 22 and things went downhill from there. All my issues just came back and became 10 times worse. Therapy didn?t seem to be helping because my old therapist moved aboard and I didn?t have the strength to find another. Even the ones he recommended weren?t good enough. So I started weed, hash, and alcohol. It?s been about 7-8 months now but I can?t find strength without at least one of the three. I have to be drunk or high to get through my awake hours and to put me to sleep. I also smoke excessively. A pack a day. It feels so much like an onset and I hate it. But I also don?t know what to do to help myself get through each day. I?m absolutely confused and tired. Cannabis and alcohol are my only solace.

Hear me out please, this is a bit crazy. So every night, right after my bf goes to work, I turn my lights off ( around 1 am, bf works 3rd shift), I hear a couple of people running the hallways. Shortly after, a terrible nauseating smell starts seeping through my apt door, vents in the bedroom, and living room. It keeps waking me up during the night. Right before 8:30 am when bf comes back home and landlord usually gets in his office, smell's completely gone. This has been going on for several months now. Told landlord, he came up here in the morning, and told me no smell of any sort, it could be food. I've been trying very hard to see who those people are, but it's pointless. No talking whatsoever, not a peep. I stand by the door sometimes for an hour just to see who they're and where they come from, the minute I step into my bathroom, I hear them running while I am in there. Landlord told me not to call cops, they have better things to do.

My addiction is not as severe as some others on here. I have been drinking 2-3 energydrinks a day since i was about 14. Maybe not 2-3 everyday, but 98% of the year. Anyway, its safe to say i have been addicted for the last 5 years. I have spent a lot of money on energydrinks, and this one of the first times i have seriously tried to stop. I stopped for about 15 days before, but that was just for a bet. Now i want to stop for real. I am about two weeks in, the store closes in an hour and i want to go down there and buy three and drink them all.

This is a mental struggle, and for some reason it is really hard not to run over to the store right now.

What do you guys do?

Also, shoutout to all the strong people in here, who are fighting, and the ones trying to help the ones struggling.

I was wondering if anyone knew of a good alternative rehab center. I once saw someone mention a place that I think was in Mexico, and they use pychadelic drugs to help you through the withdrawal. I looked it up and it sounded promising. Supposedly after just one night of using the psychedelic you?re good to go? Anyways, I can?t find it now on Google. Also I was looking at this rapid detox here in the states where they use anesthesia and use a drug to rapidly detox you while you?re under. Anyone tried that? I can?t do another traditional rehab. It just doesn?t work for me and I don?t want to use subs again. Anyone who could point me in the right direction?

I?m almost 3 months sober after being in active addiction for 3 years. My husband(who I married right before my addiction took hold)has stuck by me somehow. I?m extremely mentally ill, but I?m treated finally and stable for the first time in my life. I thought things would start to get better, but he?s started to get violent. It gets worse everytime. But I?ve done horrible things. Like. Horrible. Anyways, my question is has anyone else experienced someone lashing out in anger post addiction? I think it?s because he?s trying to heal from all the shit I?ve put him through. And because his focus isn?t just on keeping me alive. I know he has ptsd from me. I just don?t know what to do

My best friend is heading down a path of addiction to fentanyl and other pills. It breaks my fucking heart. She is like a sister to me. Every day I picture her funeral and I can?t fucking take it. From my life experience I know there is not much I can do to help besides being a good friend. But I know, if god forbid she dies before getting clean, I?ll feel like I could have done more to help. Just needed to say it to someone. Advice is welcome. Prayers for everyone struggling with this.

I?m a long term user of codeine. I have a chronic pain condition but am finding that I need more and more of it to lesson the pain. So I?ve decided it?s time to stop since I?m in pain anyway. I?ve always struggled with withdrawal symptoms when I?ve run out in the past. So I know I?m in for a rough ride. The big symptom I?ve struggled with before is coughing. I was wondering if anyone has any tips for managing the cough?

I have Valium so I?m not too worried about sleep issues and I have gastro stop for the bowel issues. I have combo panadol/nurofen for the headaches. I?m trying to get prepared. I?ll have my last dose tomorrow. Then I?m out.

Everytime I post or look at this sub I feel guilty because I keep asking for advice and help, but I'm not going to take it. I'm disgusted by what I've let myself become but I don't know any other way to be. Life is too hard to deal with sober.

Long story short my ex keeps asking me to let him comeover to my apartment to get clean. His brother who he lives with is his dealer. I told him only once his lease is up and he signs his own lease would I help him. Or if he at all proved he was serious by doing anything to prove that ... I.E. getting on MAT, getting a therapist, going to detox, or rehab. We reconnected because I originally was going to help him get on methadone and he was going to pay my rent so I didnt have to work. I got him on the program which he quit two weeks later ( the clinic was absolutely dicking us both around & is still doing it to me so I kinda don't blame him ) but I explained you need to find another clinic ASAP. It's now been almost three months of false promises and progressively less money to my landlord. He's never been sober a day in his life & has also never been through withdrawal. He keeps asking me for two days to prove he can not use? I keep feeling like I bitch for saying no. I just feel like it's a waste of time/pointless. Even if by the grace of all the gods he could not use for two days.... Then what.

I?m not an addict, codependent as hell though, extremely aware and in therapy for it.

Anyways. Yeah. He was 3 months sober. Came home. Told me replapsed.

What now? I?m not angry. Maybe a little. But mostly just like wtf. I appreciate that he told me.

I got burned by yet another person. I'm sick everything and everyone. I can't stand this anymore. I can't quit, I can't stay sober. My future is bleak and truly hopeless. I'm nothing without methamphetamine. Now I got people on my back who want to jump me for literally nothing.

I absolutely hate this existence. I don't want to go on. If I got into rehab, I'd just leave. If I were to be incarcerated, I'd be worse than I was before. I'd turn into one of them; selfish, uncaring, and sociopathic.

I want to help others. That's all I've wanted to do. I'm a shell now.

Aspirations have disappeared, hobbies are nonexistent, and morals have been depleted. Who am I? My life has been stolen right before my eyes. I'm 19 years old and I shoot up methamphetamine. The worst drug you could ever get addicted to.

There is no hope. Please find peace with my peace in accepting this. I'm just accepting it.

4 months clean from ice and really want to start dental hygiene in the fall and marry a beautiful and caring woman in the future. I want to be different than my dysfunctional family. How quickly did things turn around for you within 2 years?

I?m addicted to basically twitter, i spend 5+ hours on it. It started because I didn?t have any friends to talk to it was fine. But recently I always be there, even if I?m with friends in real life and I can?t stop.

I went to school the other day, I?m becoming a hairstylist. I was starting to set up when my instructor came up to me. He asked me to come with him, so I followed but we ended up in the education instructors office. I was then told that they had all observed some ?suspicious behavior? from me. Apparently seeming off balance, fatigued, glassy eyed, etc. I denied it the entire time because I wasn?t high or drunk. However, I was told I?d be clocked out and to go home for the night. I was terrified and angry because I was being accused of something I hadn?t done, and I could get kicked out for this.

... It?s not a drug problem I?m struggling with. It?s an eating disorder. I?m about 25-30 pounds underweight. I only eat a few different things, and I don?t eat daily. So most days I?m lethargic, don?t really think clearly, I get dizzy, etc.

I understand their concerns, but stop accusing me of being fucked up at school. Just stop. It?s only making things worse.

I know that AA and NA is a good thing for most people in recovery. I personally disagree with some of its principles, but since it's the clients view that matters, not mine, I obviously don't talk about my thoughts on it.

However, some treatment programs insist that if based on such principles. I feel this is a relic from the old days when addiction treatment was mainly done by peers, rather than Master's level professional counselors. Our training teaches us to consider a broad array of options such as harm reduction, alternative peer support groups like Recovery Dharma, etc. We definitely encourage people to attend some type of outside group simply for the connection but even that isn't a mandate; every individual js different and will have different needs. I'm a therapist as part of a very flexible IOP program with emphasis on harm reduction and motivat8onal interviewing so I feel lucky. Hopefully clients are doing their homework beforehand to see if a program subscribes exclusively to 12-step philosophy or not

i am a poly addict with schizophrenia. i went through a period of my life where the only thing that mattered to me in the world was drugs. one of my best friends died when we were 19, because of cystic fibrosis. i am almost 22 now. i just couldnt handle it. i was first addicted to benzos at 16, because i got a xanax prescription from my psychiatrist due to an "anxiety disorder" (which turned out to be the prodromal phase of my schizophrenia, and it turns out i needed antipsychotics and NOT benzos.). soon enough i was doing 10mg xanax every day, sometimes 15. it was very easy for me to keep em coming so i kept doing them. i became terrified of this and didnt talk to anyone about it and i cold turkeyed soon after. i had a seizure, had to go to the hospital and admit to benzo use. i was put on a taper program. havent touched benzos since, aside from 3 relapses that i dont feel very good about, but it is what it is.

when my friend died, i crawled into the liquor bottle and clung to it HARD. i would drink a bottle and a half of vodka every day. i would vomit in my sleep and didnt have the mental fortitude to clean up, so i would sleep in my own vomit for hours. it thought THAT was rock bottom. i was wrong. a very concerned professor of mine made me an appointment with a psychiatrist and made me promise her to go there. the psychiatrist said i immediately needed inpatient care, and soon after i was admitted to a psychiatric ward to detox from the alcohol. they gave me diazepam, despite my protests, since i already had a seizure. during withdrawals, i had my first major psychotic episode. i became incredibly paranoid, thought i was possessed, thought that i had personally killed my friend, thought i was responsible for another friends suicide, thought doctors could read and interfere with my thoughts, and i was hearing many nasty voices, always there, always commenting on everything i do. i was put on antipsychotics.

as soon as i get out of the psych ward, after a 2 month state, i start binging drugs like there is no tomorrow. i started with doing speed at parties, and it all spiraled when i discovered the world of RCs. i have binged every single RC i could get my hands on. stims, dissos, psychedelics, opioids, all of them. my mental health saw a sharp decline and i reached a point where i really didnt care anymore if i was alive or if i was dead. the highs were high and the lows were devastating. this all culminated to one day, without any significant opiate tolerance, i took 70mg morphine, 30mg oxycodone, took 7mg xanax to chase it down, and had a few drinks. naturally i stopped breathing and i turned blue in the lips and on the hands. some acquaintances found me unconscious at the front door of my apartment building and an ambulance was called. my life was saved.

when i was discharged i went on the biggest binge i have ever done in my life. i didnt sleep for a week. then i decided to do LSD, which was a terrible, terrible, terrible idea. after a trip from hell, it finally dawned on me. i have hit rock bottom. if i dont get clean NOW, i will die. i checked myself in the psych ward again, and that initial drug test came positive foe EVERYTHING they were checking for. i stayed for another two months, and this time i absolutely dedicated myself to getting clean. it had to work on myself, and i had to learn how to get my schizophrenia under control.

i made what my friends describe as a miraculous recovery. i moved back to my home country to stay with my family. i got psychiatric help and was put on medication that actually helps me function. i havent had many psychotic symptoms since. a year and a half later, i am enrolled in school and doing well, i have lots of friends and lots of hobbies, i am getting disability benefits to support myself, and i have learned many healthy ways to cope with my illness, without being destructive.

the fear of relapse looms over me every day, like a dark cloud. i keep thinking to myself, maybe you can do drugs responsibly this time, maybe you can do them just once. i do get cravings. but i know that i cant. once i start again, everything that i strived so hard to accomplish will go down the drain. if i relapse, it will be my new rock bottom. by participating in the drugs related subreddits and sharing my experiences and knowledge with other people, i have found a way to live the drug life vicariously, through others, without wanting to go back myself.

i wrote all this text because i wanted to share my story with you guys, but also as a message of hope. it gets better. it may not seem like it, but really, really, it does get better. you have to fight really hard for it, but it gets better. i never could imagine that i could live a healthy life ever again, but here i am disproving that, every day. there is always hope, never lose it. you can do it and it gets better.

My drug of choice for the longest time was booze. I have no idea how or why I became addicted. There is no obvious explanation for it. But I did and eventually that became too destructive so I found a new escape in gambling. One that I could hide from the world, and didn't risk me landing in jail or hurting someone during a blackout. I have a serious Jekyll and Hyde complex, and its scary enough that I want nothing to do with alcohol.

I've tried for years to find reprieve and have never found success. AA, GA, Counseling have been of no use. So instead I try to control it, and minimize the damage it causes. I put up barriers to prevent me from wasting our money. I send my wife my pay check (or try to, it doesn't always get there), I've intentionally tanked my credit so I can't borrow. I've disabled cash advances on my card and banned myself wherever possible from the casinos. And for the most part this stuff has allowed me to be a functional addict. I leave just room to get a taste of that escape I crave so much.

The thing is I'm miserable as all hell when I'm not gambling. I'm just surviving life until my next paycheck and my next hit. The worst part is that there is no guarantee that the "hit" is coming any time soon. The thing with gambling is the hit only comes when you win, and the system is designed to make you lose. So after waiting 14 days for my next paycheck and losing all the money I set aside for my addiction in 15 mins, my brain just begins to unravel. When I'm in this place I can't tolerate the world. I can't tolerate my job. I can't tolerate every single person in this world because for the most part they just get in the way of me doing what I want. Most regrettably I can't tolerate my wife and son (whom I love more than anything). I still find joy in doing things with them, but the daily grind of work, chores, sleep, work, chores, sleep wears me out so much that I just want to space out and then I resent them for "forcing" me to participate in life.

If this goes on for long enough, I eventually turn to the one thing that is guaranteed to give me temporary relief....the bottle. In one night I can cause so much damage that it takes years to repair and I've come dangerously close to making mistakes that can't be undone.

My wife is on the verge of leaving me. Between all the wasted money, the constant mood swings, or the fear of me coming home drunk, she is simply at her limit. And now we have a three year old son she needs to protect from me. My biggest fear before having a child was that they might inherit this from me. The reality is that I am actively guiding him down that path with my behavior but I just can't stop. I'm broken and there doesn't seem to be a fix.

I've had suicidal thoughts for years. I don't know that I was close to acting on them but they scared the hell out of me. They went away completely when my son was born. He gave me a sense of purpose and strength that I didn't know existed. I WANT to be there with him for whatever life throws his way but now I'm beginning to wonder if he would be better off without me. These thoughts are starting to creep back in my head and I'm terrified that they will get worse.

I feel better after writing this though. I've bottled it up inside for so long or maybe it's because I've only said these things before to people who just can't possibly understand. I never shared this at meetings because I didn't want to "be a downer" in rooms that were largely full of people re-affirming how much better their lives were in sobriety.

My friends and I started doing drugs casually 8 years ago. You know how it goes, we started off smoking a little weed, having a good, innocent time. At the time, we would often preach about not doing anything stronger, that weed was enough yada yada yada.

Though, as time went by, we evolved from mere stoners, into "Jacks of all Trades". LSD, MDMA, Shrooms, 2CB, Cocaine, Ketamine, Percs, and various kinds of ADHD medication, and once in a blue moon a little anti-anxiety. Even though we eventually ended up forsaking the mantra of never doing anything stronger, we still strived to treat the drugs and the frequency with respect and care. And I must admit, most of the boys are doing quite well for themselves with career, relationships, etc. We are by no stretch of our imagination doing perfect, but we can look ourselves in the mirrors (unless we're coming down from MDMA lol)

One of the boys was always the one enjoying and consuming drugs slightly more often and with a little less care, through the years. He abused MDMA at an early age and developed Serotonin Syndrome in the space of 1 year, where he really burned his fingers. After that, he would slow down a little and primarily do downers and psychs, and we thought he had learned his lesson.

Fast-forward to the summer of 2021.
My friend attended the local University and was finishing his bachelor's degree, and everything seemed to be going OK. He had passed all his exams, except 1, in which he had to attend a re-examination at the beginning of the upcoming school year. So my friend was enjoying himself through the summer and celebrating a little prematurely since he was basically done. I don't blame him, and I certainly did my fair share of drugs thru the summer, as well. He started experimenting with PCP and a lot of designer drugs thru the darkweb, and it was all fun and games until he eventually received some bad news. His study group contacted him, and basically communicated "We don't want to be in a study group with you, you aren't responsible, find somebody else." This news broke my guy, and he ended up totally spiraling out of control, especially with PCP and opiates.

He never managed to attend the final exam. He now spends all of his money on drugs.
Lends money from his parents to buy drugs. Only sleeps every second day.
Only eats a couple of times a week, and it's always cardboard pizzas.
Thrashes his apartment once in a while, when he gets angry. Goes to the hospital once in a while, we aren't even surprised anymore. When he's sober, he's just laying in bed in fetal position, he's obviously depressed. Yesterday, a fellow friend told me he started boofing heroin. The icing on the cake (or lack thereof) he fucking tried making a move on my girl man, behind my back, and he considers me one of his best friends, you know, one of the boys.

I've talked with him since, and even tho he was extremely embarrassed and regretful, it seems like all the worry, advice, and comfort we pour into him, goes in one ear and goes out the other. Nothing seems to stick.

In the space of 8 months, I've seen one of my friends fully transforming into a full-blown addict/junkie.

So, my question is: What can I do? How do I help my friend? Can I help my friend? Should I tell authorities/family?

I haven't forgiven him for making a move on my girl, but I don't wanna see him like this, it's going to kill him.

He doesn't know it's been really hard for me, because he's been in recovery from crack and narcotics for almost 2.5 years, and I don't want to make it harder for him.

I've been able to stop myself from taking them without much external help, at the most it's insisting people I live with hide anything like what I used to take and focusing on my cat when I get really bad cravings or feel like I can't keep myself from not buying any of it, but today's just... Extra hard. It always gets really hard when life gets hard, and life has been really hard, so not doing anything is hard.

They were hooked on hard stuff, and I'm sitting over here scared of myself for wanting to do whippits and I feel like they'll just think I'm silly because they haven't cared when they've seen me do so many back to back that I turn blue and pass out and no one wakes me up until it's tomorrow morning and my alarm for work is going off. They don't care I'm having conversations with my dead brother in the other room because I took half a bottle of sleeping pills and it's only a problem when I start to lose my shit and wreck the place.

I think I just don't care anymore. And that scares me a lot. And I think I just want to hear someone tell me they're proud of me for staying "sober" for... I don't even know how long, I don't count the days, but I think it would be nice to just hear someone tell me they're proud of me for staying clean, and that it would be better to keep it that way, even if the people around me don't really get that it is a struggle for me and I am having to put a lot of daily active effort into not just falling back into it all again.

I'm just really tired. And I want to give up, but I also don't, and I feel like wanting to give up is a bit stronger than not right now.

When we enter recovery it is seldom in a good place. For the most part, it is the worst possible place you have ever been. We enter it with our eyes closed and blind faith. At first, we fumble around in our sobriety and hold on to dear life counting each and every day as a miraculous achievement, and of course, it is just that. As time goes by we celebrate our achievement as another year of evolution where we have grown and matured into the adults we should have become before life and addiction took hold, different people, in different ways.

As we sink deeper into the dynamics of recovery we find we may have recovered to the degree insofar we can delve deeper into our quest. Sometimes we think of our recovery as a destination, counting of the years the date so deeply ingrained into our minds we can count down the days until our next anniversary and this is all part of the joys we find in our newfound freedom from the desire to pick up. This is an important part of our journey and the blessings and gifts along the way.*

Just for today, I am almost 9yrs sober and clean from my drugs of no choice and I realise now that the true celebration should be done each and every day we are sober and clean, as just for today suggests when we keep it in the day it lightens the load and that dates are egoic projections of a perceived race in which we are the winners or losers. Just for today, I will celebrate this day as I would any other by being kind to myself and others, by keeping an open heart and an unshakeable belief in my god of understanding/higher power.

Today I am humbled by my achievements as I reflect on my journey and marvel at my strength. I will focus on my gratitude for the things that led me here, the people, the places, and the things. The pain, sorrow, and misery of reliving an old story played on a perpetual loop our egoic mantras if you will, these stories take center stage and become our fate for more of the same. Today I will celebrate this day as I would any other by being kind to myself and others, by keeping an open heart and an unshakeable belief in my god of understanding/higher power. This higher power always serves me well and it has never failed me yet. Keep the faith. We do recover!

I first started doing meth by accident. The spring break of my senior year of college, I decided to gift myself a trip to San Francisco, for the week, to celebrate graduating from college. About half way into my trip I met a guy off of grindr with the intent to get laid. When I arrived he offered something out of this odd shaped pipe, I figured it was weed and took a puff. I was unaware that what I just smoked, was actually meth. It wasn?t until a few months later that I used again while hooking up with a couple in Seattle, this is when I made the connection to my trip to California. Fast forward to the end of August, and I found myself graduating from smoking meth to injecting it. Meth is something that is plaguing the gay community. It piggy-backs on every gay man?s false-notion that they have to have porn star sex for hours. I?ve been on this back-and-forth struggle for going on a decade now. My using has never really been consistent, every 6 months for a weekend or two, then I stop. But since losing my job in 2020 because of the Covid pandemic, my use became more frequent, happening twice a month or more for the course of a year. It?s now 2022 and nothing has change, I?m having issues maintaining a job, and my use is continuing to increase.

I know I?m unhappy, and want to change. I just don?t know where to start. I?ve been to rehab once before, and am potentially considering it again. I smoke weed as well, and Am at the point where I feel like giving everything up is the way to go. I love weed, my family has a CBD business, and even saying goodbye to that kind of gives me anxiety. Meth has helped me lose incredible jobs. It ruining my ability to have healthy sexual and intimate relationships. I know that I?m tired of living this hustle, and know I cannot maintain it much longer.

I know he's not himself. I know the things he said to me shouldn't be taken personally. I know he can't talk to me, because he's not ready to admit that he has a real problem.

But I miss my friend, and I hope that one day we can reconnect.

Some of you have friends like me... Friends who wonder if you're okay.... Friends that remember good times... friends that want you to feel better about yourself... Friends that love you... in spite of everything.

I always used smoking cigarettes as a reward. For instance I study 5hrs straight and then reward myself with a cigarette. What is a good substitute to cigarettes I can reward myself with? Other than watching something or eating.

I'm doing my recovery my own way by exercising, which actually fixes the brain and makes it more impervious to addiction. I'm going to school for dental hygiene and have a purpose again. Why do people in 12 steps try to push that on you, when science has shown exercise to be more effective for addiction?

Sometimes the shinier a person is on the outside can throw illusion on their spiritual defects of character. In the infancy of our recovery, we are, for a time blinded by our new experience, our heightened reignited senses. We often take long into our recovery and awakening to the truth to realize the man/woman with no monetary value and devoid of prestige can have the deepest heart and the safest place to rest.

Looking beyond aesthetics, prestige, and especially words often times people can mimic verbatim a healthy recovery rather than practice the work suggested herein lies great danger both to themselves moreover to the newcomer. Raw honesty over superficial godliness is a must if we wish to stay clean. Words alone will only take you as far as border control, if you wish to step into a new world you must speak your truth.

Be honest with others but more importantly be honest with yourself, this takes great bravery, courage, and strength. The most fundamental requirement for a better life is transparency, not a superficial illusion. This will ignite the god/higher power within. When we do the right thing diligently and continuously this turns into your passion. Your passion becomes a new way of life.

Some recover solely from the desire to pick up/use/act out, still wrapped up in their own unquenched pain. Oftentimes on our recovery journey without the inside work we pick up people, feelings, and resentments, they too become your new drug of choice, this will unconsciously, temporarily fill your lonely hungry heart. Stay humble on this journey. You can carry the suitcase forever, and even drag it around to each meeting or each endeavor or you can get brave and unpack. When we look at how we suffered at the hands of another it brings with it only temporary relief in the void. When you look at the contents of your life where you too were to blame for our wrongs it brings cathartic spiritual freedom from the blame game, get brave be honest. Laying all blame on others however apt is lazy and easy. Getting honest with self is where the healing is at.

I (27F) used to be a high functioning alcoholic. I had a job I was good at, I cleaned my apartment, did my laundry, paid my bills. Until I wasn't. Until my mom died last year.

I've been in therapy for 13 years for anxiety and depression. I think what finally turned me onto alcohol (when I was 20) was that it gave me so many things I couldn't give myself. It was a quick fix. It gave me a building block to begin a foundation I couldn't build on my own.

My alcoholism, depression, and anxiety co-exist now; but my alcoholism is a symptom of my mental illness, not the cause. Alcohol gave me a personality. It gave me a social life that I was too anxious to have sober. It made some of my hobbies more enjoyable. It made me not afraid to stand up for myself. It took away my shaky hands (which may be caused by anxiety, or a neurological disorder). I could do anything, handle anything.

I went to my intake today for IOP, and as soon as my clinician said "you have to look inside yourself in order to move forward," my brain short circuited. My throat started to close up with anxiety. There's nothing there. There's nothing inside me. My personality was my job, my mental illness and trauma, and school. I have no hobbies I really enjoy without alcohol. I don't enjoy talking to others. I don't know where to start. I have no motivation to find out.

I hate that I was able to get this far in life without figuring out my mental illness. I hate that all the tools they give you in IOP/Therapy haven't worked for me. I hate that I hate what I see when I look inside. I hate that I don't know what to do with that.

I was listening to the Tony Hawk Underground 2 soundtrack at work today so if you catch the reference in the title you're a star.

Anyways. I'm seriously reaching a breaking point but giving up bad habits (which at this point, let's be honest, are bad lifestyle choices) is difficult. Especially if you're leaning on them for their powerful copium. I had a bad breakup that fucked me up. Threw away FOUR YEARS of not drinking, constant AA, and now I've been drinking about this girl every day for nearly a year. Not only that but I also picked up weed again, and try not to go more than 15 mins without a cigarette in my mouth. My self esteem has never been so low. What kills me is knowing that AA and taking sobriety seriously will change my entire life; it's already done it once. But I'm so deep in this hole that the thought of living without my precious chemical pacifiers at all times feels like a fate worse than death.

I just want to stand on the top of the mountain again. I wanna know if anyone here has been in my shoes. I wanna know how you got out. I need to know I'm not alone because I'm cursed with terminal uniqueness (as they always said in AA) and somehow feel like my situation is uniquely alarming, special; and thus beyond help.

If anyone wants to chat about it, let's talk about it.

I'll try to make this as succinct as possible. My father has been an addict since he was in his 20s, and he is about 55 now. I think it started with cocaine and lead to other substances, but now it's alcohol. He has been in and out of rehab many times and has multiple DUIs. For the past 10 years or so he hasn't been able to hold down a job, and he stays at my grandparents (his parents) house. I have a few theories for how he is able to still acquire alcohol, even though his parents hide all the car keys in the house from him and don't give him money. They give him a roof over his head, food, and a pack of cigarettes whenever he asks.

Growing up he was emotionally and physically abusive to me and my mom, so obviously our relationship is not the best. I will always love him because he is my dad, but I do make it an effort to keep a fair distance. Recently he has been drinking a lot, and apparently it has been pretty bad. My grandmother called me last week and is begging for me to convince my grandfather (her husband) to send my dad to a rehab facility. My grandparents are incredibly wealthy so cost is not an issue, but my grandfather doesn't think another round of rehab is going to do anything.

I have had to play the role of the parent child many times in my life, and I am in therapy for all that I have been through. As much as I feel that it is not my responsibility to have this conversation since I am the kid, my grandmother is so scared that something is going to happen to my Dad I think she's desperate.

I obviously want my dad to get better. My mom always tells me stories of how amazing he was when they first met and during the first few years after I was born. The only reason I have doubts is because of what comes after rehabilitation. Yes my dad will go into a program for 3 months, but what will he do after? Are there some form of work programs for recovering addicts? I'm just worried that he is going to return to the same house, and fall into the same habits as before. And it will all be for nothing.

Maybe a stupid question as in my opinion addiction is all about willpower and discipline of NOT doing what you addicted too.

Unfortunately it ain't easy as I struggle myself on this front.

Just wondering. Let's say you are 20 years addicted to something. How long would it take to cure this addiction - is there a time frame 40 days or 100 days or longer to see a noticeable difference?

When does the pattern kicks in your brain that you won't crave for the addiction?

so i'm an alcoholic, but i'm 30 something days sober (woohoo!). all of my friends and family members are super stoked for me and im doing a lot better for the most part; finally motivated enough to clean, shower, and generally take care of myself again.

i'm really proud of myself too. ive been enthusiastic about recovery and i even went to a meeting about a week ago (wasn't really my thing, but glad i tried it).

on another hand, one of the reasons i've been able to stay "sober" is because i recently started using amphetamines.

i don't feel like this is a case of swapping one addiction for another. using them doesn't make me spiral into self destruction like drinking did, but i still get a pang of guilt when the people i love tell me that they're so proud of me for being "sober".

don't get me wrong, i'd love to be able to get through the day without needing substances to cope, but at this point in time it's not realistic.

I thought I?d share some things about my experience as an addict. I?m 25, male. I watched Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas when I was twelve and after it finished I walked back to my bedroom as if I was on ether, downloading Hunter?s personality completely. My sisters friend told her I was ?fucked? when he found out it was my favourite movie and novel. Despite how dark the trips were in the movie I romanticised it. Just like I romanticised the life of Kurt Cobain and Jim Morrison, my idols. I carry the pain of being a creative entity. Feeling too much and forever living inside of my head. I smoked weed from 12 onwards and binged alcohol at parties. I became fascinated with psychonaut explorations with psychedelics from age 16 onwards despite the ghost tour guide in high school telling me psychedelics ?damage your spiritual webs?. When I was 18 I got drug induced psychosis for a year from eating a meth pill. I continued to use and party regardless. 5 years later age 23 I went to rehab. It saved my life. From drinking morning to night, from snorting mountains of crushed dexamphetamine and benzos. From spending my rent money on ketamine. I?ve hit rock bottom so many times and relapsed so many times back into the depths of psychosis, nearing death and hurting loved ones and still I ?choose? to use. I keep falling back into the trap of romanticising the emotional pain of addiction and life. But with every relapse it gets easier to stop using. Right now I?m abusing coffee and cigarettes, caffeinated into oblivion. Stoicism is my philosophy of nature. Although I do become quite nihilistic when I?m coming down. The quest to know yourself never ends and you must know yourself well to pull yourself out of addiction. Just remember recovered addicts blossom into the most beautiful people. After traversing the extreme lows of emotions addiction creates you come back even better than ever in sober time.

I?m starting to feel like it?s NOT an issue of ?motivation? or ?determination? because, whenever I?m in the midst of withdrawal, I have PLENTY of motivation?to go pick up and get high. It works against me.

I almost called my dealer today, well I actually did call him but I hung up. I left to hang out with my girlfriend instead. I?m glad I?m not on here writing ?well time to restart? Do you y?all have ideas to do (like hobbies or activities) to distract me from temptation, any would be appreciated!

Cocaine, Alcohol and Gambling. The recipe for disaster. I can?t tell anyone, so I go back to my dealer to ask for more cocaine to escape my mind. I end up looking for porn and end up talking to people I would pass on the street.

I?m looking for jobs but I hate interviews. I?m broke and everyone?s moving so fast. Life is moving fast and I honestly don?t know what to do. I?m struggling to put one foot I front of the other to allow myself to become happy.

I?m going to try and keep this short and to the point because it?s a complicated family issue. My aunt has a lot of mental health and alcohol issues. She was living with her daughter for 15 years until her daughter kicked her out back in September. Long story short, my aunt was being verbally and mentally abused by her grandson?s friends that now controlled that house and she cried everyday about it to me. Finally, my aunt stood up for herself and told the manager that these guys were living there without being added to the lease and the manager told them the guys have to move out. That?s why her daughter kicked her out. Anyway, my aunt moved into a cheap motel for 2 weeks until I finally gave in and told her she could stay with me for a few months until she saves up some money and gets her life in order. I found a room 3 months later within walking distance from me so we checked it out and she agreed to live with a friendly woman also in her 60s. Everything seemed like it was working out, my aunt seemed to have her life in order again. Then her best friend called me 4 days ago and asked me to take my aunt back in. I asked why, this friend told me the new housemate was taking advantage of my aunt financially, basically my aunt paid for a Costco membership, paid for all the groceries, etc. Apparently my aunt bought this lady and herself a 12 pack of beer every night and they were drinking excessively.

So I told my aunts friend, I?ll talk to the both of them and see if we can get this resolved. The friend asked why I just don?t take my aunt back and I told her that I want to try and talk to them first. Her friend then goes, ?well she drinks a lot with this lady, when she stays with you, she only has a 6 pack every night?? I kinda hinted to her friend that that?s the whole problem.

So I need some advice, should I try moving my aunt back in and deal with her BS until I find a new housemate for her or do I tell her she needs to stand up for herself, don?t pay for everything and cut down on her drinking?

It?s so mentally draining for me because my aunts friend accuses me of not caring since I have an empty room available.

Basically, I feel even if I got her a new housemate and found her a new room to rent, she?d still fall into trouble because she can?t say no to people. She insists on paying for everything and she likes to buy beer for people because she wants people to drink a lot with her everyday. So yes, the housemate is probably taking advantage of that but a lot of other people would be doing the same and I tell my aunt to stop paying for people and start learning how to say no. She claims she?s afraid people won?t like her if she says no. I always cringe when she tells me that because it sounds like something a child would say. Anyway just wanted to add this last part on so that you guys can understand the whole context.
