For background information, I?m a 19-year-old girl who?s diagnosed with ADD (same thing as ADHD minus the hyperactivity). I?ve been taking prescription Adderall since I was about 12 years old. Mind you, despite how over-prescribed Adderall supposedly is, it was something I definitely needed at the time. I had a traumatic event happen to me as a child involving my father (who was addicted to painkillers and alcohol), and I believe the trauma has something to do with my ADD because I started showing symptoms shortly afterwards, though I didn?t get medicated for it until years later. Also, I got diagnosed with PTSD and anxiety as a direct result of the trauma.

I know Adderall is a controlled substance that can lead to addiction, which is why I?m seeking answers about this. I can?t tell if what I?m going through is an addiction or not. Let me explain:

After being prescribed Adderall at age 12, I took it normally and consistently (once a day throughout the 5-day school week). I had a much easier time focusing in class and my grades improved significantly. This was the case up until I was about 15 years old, when my doctor suggested that I start taking Adderall twice a day (once in the morning, once in the evening). I started to realize how much I liked the way Adderall made me feel. Whenever I took it, it made me feel like I was capable of doing anything I put my mind to. I?d pull all nighters and spend the entire night sketching, writing, or doing anything productive, all while I popped more pills than I was supposed to take. There were times where I?d take 5 pills a day. At that point, I was also at the peak of my eating disorder (anorexia nervosa), and frequently I?d take Adderall just to get rid of my appetite. It made me lose a lot of weight.

The reason why I?m not sure if this is an addiction is because when I eventually had to stop taking it so often, I couldn?t tell whether my symptoms were from withdrawal or simply normal side effects of coming down from the medication. After spending so many days and nights on it, spending a day without it was just?exhausting. I?d be fatigued, irritable, and sometimes feel physically ill the entire day. There was a time where I binged on Adderall for nearly 48 hours, then I finally went to sleep around 3 a.m., and woke up at 8 p.m. later that same day. That long crash was most likely due to how sleep deprived I was in general, but I?ve crashed for extensive periods after taking Adderall when I wasn?t necessarily sleep deprived before.

Another thing that convinces me that this might be an addiction is already having an addictive personality, and being predisposed to addiction due to how much it runs in my family, including my father. This is what worries me the most.

Would anybody be able to tell me if it sounds like I?m addicted to Adderall or not? I realize it probably sounds like a stupid question, but drug addiction is very serious and I want to make sure I?m not blowing it out of proportion before I reach out for help. Please don?t hesitate to be honest, this is something I really want to know so I can figure out how to approach it when I talk to my loved ones about it.

I was asked this last night at a convenience store. I was buying 2 sugar free Dr. Peppers and a pack of chocolate twinkles to go with my 2 one foot long steak sandwich and loaded french fries. I was going home to gorge myself and then go right to sleep. I love eating big meals then going to sleep. I know it's not healthy, but I do it anyway. I prefer to eat a lot before sleeping. I don't care if it fucks up my body. I don't care if my teeth fall out. I just don't fucking care. Maybe if I told the gas station clerk this, maybe next time I come in she won't ask me to smile. She'll know that I have nothing to smile for. I have no reason to smile. I'm going home to stuff my face with thousands of calories and tons of fat and cholesterol. I never smile. Life isn't something I smile at. People aren't something I smile at. I go through life with a deep dark bottomless expression on my face. No one talks to me and I don't talk to anyone. Just trying to get though this as fast and efficiently as possible. I work nights because of this. You can't see me, and I can't see you. I leave the lights off on my off airport parking shuttle bus until I have to put them on. People get on my bus and start talking about their trip. I shut those fucking lights off. Everyone goes quite. I don't turn the lights on until I reach the off airport parking lot. I hurry around back to get the luggage off before the people get there. I keep my head down and my hood up. I keep my sunglasses on as long as I can. I try to have as little human interaction as humanly possible. Just give me my tip or not and leave. Actually I don't care if I get tip. If I get a tip I feel obligated to talk. To say thank you. At least if you give me nothing, I will have no reason to go further with the interaction. Coworkers want to spark up conversations. I know I can't just not respond. I say the most fucked up off the wall work appropriate shit I can think of. A guy ask me about some pizza place up the street. Asked me why it's never open. Askes me if I've ever been there. I say yeah I've been there to buy heroin. End of conversation. What can he say? He can't even ask if I'm joking because I say it straight face and act dead serious. Younger coworkers ask me questions. I go into a life sucks then you die rant. The only peace is when you die. You die and have no worries. Bills , work, family obligations, society obligations all gone. You just fucking die and thats it. I say this dead seriously with a straight face. Then the deathly silence takes over. Minutes pass and nothing else is said. The young coworkers just sit there and think of a response, but can't think of anything. They know I'm right. They know that there generation is fucked. 20 years old and in college for some bullshit degree. Working at a off airport parking lot for extra beer money. Happy go lucky until I start to talk. It's beautiful. The hopes and dreams are rushed away at a blink of a eye. They realize that I'm right. I walk out of the office to my van in the parking lot. I leave them with there thoughts. I go on another trip to the airport. I drive back and forth over and over again. 10, 11 hours a night. I radio on the cb to the dispatcher. No more glee in their speaking. No more friendly banter or chit-chat. I hear the nothingness in their voice over the radio. I'm not trying to make these people depressed and without hope. It just comes extremely natural to me. Customers are happy they're going on vacation and try to talk to me about it. I hear the happiness in their voices. It's a 10 minutes ride to the airport. 10 minutes is all I need. They get off the bus still happy, but not without wondering. Wondering if that bus driver will still be alive when I get back. Thinking that how can he not be as happy as I am. I'm going vacation, why not spread my joy to everyone I can before I reach my final destination? No. Not on my shift. You're trying to make me feel your excitement is having a negative effect on me. The more you try to talk to me about how happy you are, the more I'm trying to derail you happiness. I drop them off and radio in to dispatch. I hear no happiness or excitement. I give no happiness or excitement. I return to the off airport parking lot. This goes on for the next 9 hours.

A close family member has been in an on off relationship with a guy who is a poly drug user for over a year.

During the time together she has 'willingly' given him a fairly sizeable portion of her income. She has helped to support him through his drugs issues and has on occasions been assertive with him about not wanting her home turned into a crack den. He had predominantly been smoking crack and they had split due to his not being able to have sex(weak erection, no pre cum, little desire) buy had remained close.

Last night she called to say that he was threatening, out of the blue, to delete her number and return her belongings because of something she had done which he wouldn't elaborate on and that he seemed to be on a crack withdrawal or had taken benzos. When this happens her resolve to help him crumbles and she will buy him a new mobile or replace whatever belonging he has had which he has managed to 'lose' or break (read sell) and/or will self harm and spend money on him (often well in excess of what she can afford).

This behaviour seems to be cyclical ie. the last time it happened was before their split where he had said he couldn't see a future for the two of them as there had been too many 'problems' and he had lost his taste for the relationship. This resulted in my family memeber self harming in his presence and then purchasing a large quantity of cigarettes and a mobile phone which resulted in him agreeing to remain friends for life.

In recent days he has been threatening to end the friendship and my relative has admitted to trying to stall things by transferring nearly 500 pounds into this guy's account. He has stated that his friendship cannot be bought but appears content to hold onto the money which amounts to nearly 3/4 of a month's wage.

My relative is well versed in addiction and addictive personalities and understands that the drugs have replaced his personality but she is unable to find a way out in part because he is the sweetest most attentive person for weeks on end and then all of a sudden there will be some trivial reason for which he needs to cut her out of his life for good which results in her desperately trying to buy him back into her life on whatever terms he wants.

Is the burden of ambivalence part of my age group's natural maturation phase? I think not. Atypical up-bringing, atypical brain chemistry, and a typical predispositions - how could I not be a statistical outlier?

Black and white can never assimilate and chaos follows, especially since they're so close together.

Polarized politics, polarized diets, polarized street addresses, polarized needles, polarized numbers, and polarized leisure activities.

Thinking in black and white is a logical fallacy and a cognitive distortion. I've been enlightened - I'm illogical in that area. The burden of ambivalence is prevalent, and has been very prevalent throughout my entire adolescence, come to find out.

I was diagnosed with pretty severe ADHD in 2nd grade and ever since then I've been on and off different medication for it.

About 2 years ago I was prescribed Adderall, and it finally felt like the med that helped me the most. The Adderall caused me to have an eating disorder, so my doctor switched me to Ritalin. After taking Ritalin for only a week, withdrawal symptoms started. I couldn't handle any emotion, slept for 12+ hours a night, and became very depressed. I asked my doctor to switch me back onto Adderall, and she did. Now that I'm back on it, I constantly feel like I need more. I'll take my dose in the morning, and half way through the day I find myself wanting more. I've even snorted it a few times at school just because whenever I feel like I want more, I become very out of it and emotionless.

If anyone could help me out I would greatly appreciate it. To be honest I don't even know if this is an actual addiction. All I know is I feel like shit constantly, and I'm abusing my prescription.

Could go into a lot more detail about the variety of mental illnesses I've been diagnosed with, but I'm (mostly) high-functioning. I have always been depressive, more than anything else, and right now I find myself achieving very little.

I have a psychiatrist, and I'm looking to change meds right now as they're not effective, but I know that smoking weed is both a symptom and cause of my low mood. I spent 5 years clean, and did a lot of exercise during that time - I love fitness, particularly running, jiu-jitsu and yoga, but find myself doing vanishingly little of any of them at the moment in favour of smoking weed and playing call of duty.

I don't have a source of income but I don't have immediate financial pressure. The result is that I wake up in the morning and smoke with my coffee. I love it, but at the same time I'm incredibly bored of my lifestyle. I have a life coach and a psychologist too and they seem to help a little, but I'm capable of doing so much with my life and I'm currently doing next to nothing. I'm not even interested in the things I'm usually interested in, e.g. reading. Instead I'm wasting away, addling my brain and watching life go by for me. Would love to get back to my positive addictions, going for runs and doing jiu-jitsu and meeting new people (i live alone) doing yoga. Not sure what to do and any advice would be well-received.

The stigma of addiction in America and lack of understanding is so frustrating. Its 2022, and tons of people still believe addiction is a ?choice? or a ?moral issue?. Science has shown addiction to be a brain disease and chemical imbalance for over 2 decades.

The common belief is that ? drugs are the cause of addiction?. That?s just not true. Drugs are a symptom of addiction, but not the cause. Addiction starts long before drugs are introduced. Most addicts have been seeking some form of dopamine and seratonin rush since a child (sex, food, video games, excercize).

So why can normal people drink with moderation or do coke once a year and not think about it again, while addicts ruin their lives with them? Because of the chemical imbalance and brain disease an addict has dealing with pleasure. 9/10 addicts use to self medicate.

At the end of the day, choosing to put a drug in your body is a choice, yes. But having

There?s a strong stigma associated with addicts? particularly meth addicts. The stigma is bullshit. Yes, there are piece of shit addicts? like there are piece of shit non-addicts. Similar rates in both groups if I had to make an educated guess. I?m a little biased FOR addicts because I?ve met some of the best people I?ve ever known who happen to also be daily drug users. If they started out with a solid view of the world and some empathy and decent work ethic? they usually became a fucking cool addict.

Maybe there?s more to it than that.. but all I know is some people do well in addiction. Hence why you don?t hear about their story? they don?t have horror stories to tell. They don?t plead for help to achieve sobriety online (no judgment if you have, though). They don?t go to N/A meetings. When the pain becomes intolerable, some doctors prescribe Vicodin. It is a prescription painkiller developed to provide relief to patients with moderate or severe pain. It is made up of opioid pain relievers and non-opioid pain relievers. In other words, it contains Hydrocodone and Acetaminophen. The Hydrocodone present in Vicodin is a synthetic opioid, which activates the same neurotransmitter as heroin.

Vicodin tablets come in three different dosage levels of hydrocodone- 5 mg, 7.5 mg, and 10 mg. Each of the Vicodin tablets contains 300mg to 325 mg of Acetaminophen. Generally, it is prescribed to be taken a single tablet, after every 4-5 hours. When taken for a long time, it can have a habit-forming effect.

What Vicodin Addiction is

Vicodin is currently labeled as a schedule II controlled substance according to the Drug Enforcement Agency (DEA) after being removed from schedule III in October 2014. Since the additional potential of Vicodin was so high, the DEA tightened the restrictions in order to prevent fraud and to ensure the safety of the citizens who can get addicted to it.

The addiction to Vicodin includes every type of use without a prescription. One of the results of Vicodin addiction is liver damage or failure. Severe cases of liver damage, involve the dose of 4000 mg or more of Vicodin or Acetaminophen in a single day.

Effects of Vicodin Addiction

Every addictive substance comes with side effects, so Vicodin too has side effects. The most common side effect of it is liver damage. Some of the other side effects of the Vicodin include:

 Drowsiness

 Dizziness

 Relaxed and calming experience

 Light head

 Constipation

 Decreased breath rate

 Depressed heart rate

 Aches and cramps

 Nausea vomiting

 Muscle pain

 Depression

Vicodin Addiction?s Symptoms

It is tough to identify the addiction to Vicodin most of the time. Because most people don?t realize that they are getting dependent on it. They realize when they stop taking it.

In order to diagnose the substance use disorder, the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorder (MSM-5) outlines some criteria. To diagnose, a person needs to meet two or more of the corresponding criteria within 12 month period. When a patient meets two or three criteria, he may have a mild substance use disorder. On the other hand, meeting four to five criteria are considered moderate and six or more is for the severe substance use disorder.

Some symptoms of Vicodin addiction are mentioned below:

 Taking Vicodin in larger amount or longer than prescribed

 Want to cut down the dose but not able to manage

 Taking more time getting, using, or recovering from the use of Vicodin

 Strong urge to use Vicodin

 Not able to concentrate on work, home, or school.

 Giving up on important occupational, social, or leisure activities

 Development of withdrawal symptoms

Vicodin Addiction Treatment

The most effective treatment can be provided by professionals only. Vicodin addiction treatment includes therapy and support in an environment that is specially created for recovery. It becomes more effective when patients join support groups and learn from the stories of others about how to sustain a drug-free life.

An expert?s supervision helps them recover fast as compared to patients without direction and supervision. If you have a close relative or friend who is dealing with Vicodin addiction, you can save their life by seeking professional help.

I?m in what I?d consider to be the second honeymoon phase. My mind is clear and focused. My emotions are balancing out. My stress levels are the lowest they?ve been in years. Oddly enough, I had an intense using dream last night, which I guess is my mind?s way of saying ?not so fast? as the curtain of addiction continues to lift. It?s been 15 years of this shit, man. I?ve made countless attempts at sobriety, ranging from a couple hours to 14 months, and I?ve never wanted so badly to make substance use part of my past. I got clean this time because I was once again losing my grip on reality. I was hearing voices. I was broke. I was bottoming out. My days as a functioning addict were over.

Something I?ve been thinking about a lot lately is the idea of psychological addiction. I?ve never had much in the way of physical withdrawals. Opiates were never my cup of tea. My most recent cycle was daily marijuana use followed by two to three day Adderall binges. Wax on, wax off. But any addictive substance, even something as comparatively harmless of marijuana, produces physical changes in neurotransmission. The brain makes a maladaptive adjustment to substance use, etching it into daily life. I fell into this cycle originally because I completely misunderstood that concept. Addiction is not what I thought it was. It is so much worse. It takes over the mind. It robs you of the essential you, and you?re the last one to know it. There?s nothing I want more than than to pass this knowledge onto the younger generation, people like myself who have no idea that they?re getting themselves into something truly terrible, but at the same time I consider it to be a fool?s errand. Would I have listened when the drugs were a novel and truly exhilarating experience? I don?t think so.

The first time I consciously tried to get clean was over ten years ago. During this repeated cycle of recovery and relapse, I?ve lost so many friends. My best friend didn?t invite me to his wedding. There was never a falling out. People simply distanced themselves from me. I?m a liability. I?ve missed out on so much. Some days I feel nothing but regret. Other days I make peace by reminding myself I?m a more humble, more caring, and more understanding person because of the havoc addiction has inflicted on my life. I intimately understand failure. I know what it?s like to be objectively in the wrong. I?ve done some truly awful things that keep me up nights. My sober mind struggles to reconcile my actions in active addiction, and if I?m not careful that alone will make me relapse. There are so many triggers, so many trauma points, that sometimes I just want to scream. Or drive 100 mph into a brick wall, ending this struggle for my sanity altogether. Or get high. This week I feel great. A week ago I was at my wit?s end. That?s just how it goes.

Yesterday I visited my dad?s farm. Here in Ohio we?ve taken so much snow in the past couple days that I haven?t been able to work. I drive for UberEats, but I have a RWD vehicle. It handles well in the snow, but it?s prone to getting stuck when we get dumped on. Boredom is my worst enemy. I was so restless that I made the half hour journey to see my pops and the animals. Really I just wanted to play with the new puppy. We scurried around in the snow. The pup, me, and the adult dog of the same breed. My heart was filled with so much love and joy. I wasn?t concerned about my reup. I wasn?t in a rush to get home to my bong. I wasn?t frantic because I?d spent all my disposable income and then some ($400+/month on weed alone). I was truly in the moment, staying for dinner and chatting with my dad and his wife into the late night. I thought about how free I felt, how substances no longer run my life, and it?s enough to bring grown man to tears. Addiction is a nightmare. I don?t think you understand that until you break the cycle. Like what the fuck was I doing? That?s not life. This is.

My girlfriend and I sent messages back and forth when I got home. I slipped off to sleep with ease. Yet it was a night of using dreams. A day of recovery punctuated by the invisible hand trying to yank back into that lifestyle, the sickening fond memories of highs long gone, a reminder that I will live with this hideous affliction the rest of my life. Someone tell my 16 year old self that the drugs aren?t worth it. I?m 31, and I?m just now beginning to live.

I'm struggling with the whole concept of "recovery" and the nature of addiction and mental illness. Im addicted to weed and relationships (codependency). I would be addicted to worse things if I let myself be exposed to them, but i know myself well enough to not put myself in those situations.

My question is, if you have this kind of "addictive personality" (i.e. mental illness, OCD in my case).....what does recovery even look like??? I find it impossible to conceptualize a future where I dont have an unhealthy underlying NEED for something. Whether its weed, a relationship, sugar, sex, attention, etc. If I gave up all of this to be healthier and focus on myself.....id probably develop one of my hobbies to an addictive, unhealthy degree, like my partially-recovered alcoholic dad has done with running/working out.

To be clear, I am currently medicated for OCD and it definitly helps, but I find it hard to believe any combination of therapy and drugs will ever solve my addictive tendencies. Is there hope? Is there a point in recovery where you wake up and realize "Hey, I dont feel an unhealthy desire for anything/anyone. Guess I am 100% recovered"???

In my experience, there are several different stages of addiction. The first being the complete belief that you are in control, having a good time and that its something that you want to do..Then comes the consequences, the occasional moment of clarity when you realise that you started the day with one intention, but ended up with something completely different. I.e. going out for one drink, waking up after a blackout 2 days later. For many, the consequences happen very quickly, for some, it takes years to develop into a problem. There is quite a lot of denial at this stage. NOBODY wants to be labelled 'addict' and further more, nobody like the idea that they have no power of their problem, that their willpower is basically zero and some instinctual pleasure seeking part of the brain is overriding any rational thought whatsoever.

So, this is mainly a bitch because I feel so deflated. On Saturday I broke 2.5 years sobriety. I have comorbid bipolar and I turned into my full monstrous drunk manic self. Since Saturday all ive want to do is drink again to switch of the guilt, to feel a minute of peace. But I also never want to drink again because I never want to hurt my friends in that way ever again. So, I made an action plan. I reach out to a local charity for drug, alcohol abuse and offending behaviours as well as my mental health practioner. Today the charity told me they can't take me on because they don't consider a blip active addiction. That they can't offer me a support worker because I'm not enough of an addict. They offered me online support group support meetings as an alternative.

As far as I read a bad habit is formed as a response and is triggered by external factors. Like people who smoke during their break or when they are stressed.

So the habit is created when they are in a specific situation and so quitting cold Turkey is hard because you still have that habit.

So I thought if you would randomize your destructive behavior without a fixed time or a specific external event triggering it and then tapering down would that help with the fight against addiction?

Male, 21 years old and come from a family with addiction issues. Started drinking in high school at parties and on weekends sometimes, never became a daily issue at the time.

It was when I started smoking weed around graduation that I realized I have addiction issues because I smoked pretty much everyday since then (3 years ago now) and have tried to quick pretty much everyday since and failed. Put the weed down cause of anxiety in Dec 2020 and picked up drinking. Boy oh boy was I in for a ride of a life time. What followed was Jail, misery, hopelessness, complete severance of relationships, regret, financial problems, etc. Keep in mind i?m not diagnosed depression or pretty much anything. before alcohol the first 20 years of my life were just fine and completely normal. I come from a VERY close family of 7 people, (2 married parents of 30 years and 4 siblings of whom i?m very close with) Which goes to show just how incredibly powerful this drug is and what it can do to even somebody who is well situated.

Was always self aware of everything I did and what I was doing to myself, just couldn?t stop. I went from drinking 2-3 Tall cans of beer daily in December 2020 to drinking 1 litre of vodka daily by the time May 2021 came. I pretty much dealt with what a typical alcoholic would have dealt with in the span of their 40 year battle per say, but crammed into the span of 5 months. It was ridiculous.

Went to rehab June 1st 2021, haven?t drank since. That is? until 5 days ago. I am fed up with these labels I give myself and believing that I cannot sip on alcohol for the rest of my life. I?m a person who is hyper-aware of addiction and how it works as I study it all the time and live it, so I have come to the conclusion that if I am in a good place in my life and feel stable, I can drink. And to put it simply, so far, so good?

I?m that person who is talking to my friend at the bar and while he?s telling me something, i?m just thinking about how he hasn?t sipped on his drink for the past 10 minutes.. wondering how? why? because I would have had my first 3 beers finished in 5 minutes to get the convos started. I am FASCINATED by people who leave the bar with their drinks half full, it doesn?t compute in my brain. Relatable eh?

Therefore, i?ve taken this knowledge and I am now applying it to my lifestyle. I drank one beer on January 10th, decided to leave a little bit in the glass as I walked out. Drank another beer January 12th, left a little bit in the glass again. Drank 2 beers tonight, stopped myself before going further.

I know I am putting myself at risk for what happened last time, all i?m trying to say is that I guess for a person that has brain abnormalities (addiction predisposition), it is taking A LOT of will power to do this, but so far I feel like I can do this. I?m not saying that all of a sudden I don?t have those addict tendencies like before, it took absolutely EVERYTHING inside of me to leave those last sips in and walk away, and to not go to the liquor store and get more, because fuck I really wanted to. So I guess for us ?addicts? if you want to drink again, obviously you can BUT it WILL come at a price. And that price for us ?alcoholics? is a very, very strong will power and mindset to control it. Some of us just may not be able to afford it.

Not intended to encourage drinking again, just my thoughts and experiences so far

(Story resumes here)

Everything I said in that story I firmly believed. All it took was about a week and what I found is that I quickly started to care less about my principals and routines and started picking up 1 more beer than I planned to per night and so on. It?s absolutely astonishing but I get it now. If you cannot drink in moderation, I genuinely now believe you never will. I have a disease, similar to somebody who deals with diabetes and requires insulin to survive. What I require is total sobriety and it pains me but at this point all I want is to be sober. I?ve spent countless nights begging god, the universe, whatever you believe in to heal me of this and let me sober and not buy a substance the next day but I end up doing it because, well, addiction. It?s a fucking pain in my ass. As it is for all of you beautiful people who are here to help and support.

I didn?t really think much about typing all this but i?m really drunk right now (Two 750ml bottles of vodka in to be exact) and I thought i?d just wing it because it?s getting me out of my head and all i?m looking for is ideas, responses, love, just something. I know I need to quit now and i?ve planned to set my first day tomorrow for the rest of my life. It?s just fucking god damn hard when you?re only 21 and have the illusion that you have the rest of your 20?s to party, have fun, get fucked up, have sex, pursue maximum dopamine release etc. I guess my main message here is for somebody who is an alcoholic, or as doctors put it, alcohol use disorder, we just can?t fucking drink. Just can?t. Unless you?re prepared to end up in Jail, loose your family, all relationships, become depressed and anxious etc. I love you alcohol, but I hate you.

My oldest brother, 40, and another older brother, 38, are both life long addicts, starting somewhere shortly after high school. My oldest got into heroin and opiates and has always lived with my mom, recently transitioning into meth on and off a few years ago. The other one was straight into uppers and never got the same leniency with my mom.

The 40 year old is entirely dependent on my mom financially, hasn't held down a job and hasn't even tried to be employed in 4 or 5 years. The 38 year old is in prison.

It's frustrating me because my mom can barely make rent, I find myself lending her money to just make ends meet and she refuses to acknowledge that it all stems from extra expenses for the 40yo as well as money on the 38 yo's books. She earns more than I do but has horrible money management and constantly lives paycheck to paycheck. The 40yo has always been welcome at her house and contributed little to nothing. What's worse, he is constantly venting to me about how toxic our mom is and how much she holds him back. He has a drug fueled religious fervor that has led him to write biblical passages on the wall and draw biblical scenes in sharpie when he is high all around their apartment. He has become angry and threatened violence if she even suggests that there are areas in which he could improve and constantly says the drugs aren't an issue. It's hard for me to argue because his life choices have never led to any of the consequences that would normally accompany a lifelong drug habit.

The 38 yo has never had the same leniency. He has lived on the streets and committed crimes to support his habit. Things the 40yo has never had to worry about.

Since I was about 8, all we have ever talked about as a family is one of these two brothers and I (29) am feeling more and more exhausted with it. My mom will invite me over to their appt (with sheets pinned over the windows and sharpie writing everywhere) and acts like if we all eat dinner and watch TV we can collectively pretend like everything is normal. Or if she comes over to my house or my other brother's (non-addict) house she thinks it's unfair that we aren't comfortable with the 40 yo there. It just feels delusional.

The 40 yo always says I'm the only person he can talk to and trust and I try to play a supportive role/ gently nudge him the right way. But at a certain point the pattern has to stop. The conversation always turn to how toxic Mom is in his eyes, which obviously makes me try to encourage him to get a job and move out, but he blows it off and acts like she's the one who needs to change and be more encouraging of his bizarre, constantly changing life goals. His stance stems from the idea that "families need to support each other all the time, regardless of their problems" but doesnt see the hipocrisy and the fact that he has never supported anyone, even himself.

We have tried interventions with all 3, including trying to convince my mom to stop enabling. But she can't bear to do it and is convinced that the 40yo isn't strong enough to survive any tough love. In her mind, he will starve or overdose the moment she stops enabling so she just keeps doing what she's doing. Her intentions, although misguided, are always about helping them. She would starve and live in the cold, and almost has, if it meant they were warm and fed.

I'm 17 with addictions. I?ve recently recognized that I have an addictive personality. I immediately become hooked on any substance or activity that provides dopamine. I begin violently craving them to the point that it is the only thing I can think about and when I?ll do it next. Here?s a brief list of past and/or current addictions (from least to worst destructive). Feel free to skip around, summary at the end.

Food

It?s the only consistent addiction in my life. I?ve been doing it since I was about 11. I?m not obese or anything but I wish I had control over what goes into my body, and I wouldn?t mind losing some weight. I?ve eaten 4000 calories in a sitting to fill that void, usually followed by a day of strict restriction. I think that I regain control by over eating. People

I become absolutely obsessed with people I?m attracted to, which is normal, but I feel that I am on an extreme end of the spectrum. Within the first week of meeting the person they usually consume my every thought. Hence my strict no dating policy for myself.

shop lifting

This one was short lived. I did it for the first time in august and the last time in December. I think and hope it was the last time. Something about the rush of adrenaline during and after made it unbearable to resist. And getting away with it, well I was nothing less than a god in the moment. I realized it was a problem when I did it when I was with my mom, dad and sisters. I stole a small magnet. After leaving the store, while still high on the adrenaline, I showed off my token. My mother pulled me aside and rightfully so reprimanded me. I didn?t care in the moment but in hindsight it was devastating.

Wreckless driving

This is one that I try not to do because I know that it could end up with others injured or worse. The funny thing about addiction is that in the moment you do not care about anyone else, the ?high? is the only important thing. I?ve never been this type of person, I?ve always- well I still am, I am tender, kind and thoughtful. But my personality is pushed to the side when I have a chance to receive the high I need. This is devastating to me because I do not wish to harm anyone.

Self harm

Im not sure what this one is about. I?m not sure if I subconsciously think that I deserve the pain, or do I like the control, or maybe its the blood. I?m not sure. This one was very short lived as well but severe while it lasted. For about a month I would cut every day, sometimes multiple times a day. It was my release when I had overeaten, when I was overwhelmed or when I hated myself. I had a panic attack when I flew across the country because I knew that there would be no way for me to cut while I was there. That day was my first day of just over two months clean. I?ve since come home and have had minor urges but have been able to resist.

Alcohol

Ive only drank a few times for good reason. The hang over is no fun. I still do get the craving for it despite the pain it will cause the next day. It shoots me into a world besides my own where I am able to be worry free and that?s amazing, but unhealthy. It feels as though I am a toddler again, before I went though everything I went through. My rock bottom was probably drinking stolen vodka out of a coke bottle in my room alone at midnight. This was when I realized that I had spun out of control. I don?t think I have ever become addicted to alcohol but I definitely have the potential to become given my history.

Weed

This one is a combination of the effect from self harm and alcohol. it provides a release but I?m not truly addicted. Weed provides me with a release not an escape. It shushes my racing mind for just enough time for my body to catch up. I would not find my use of weed concerning if it were recreational, but its not, it?s a release and a coping mechanism. That makes it unhealthy.

Adderall

I would like to make it clear that this is by prescription. I have adhd and take it daily, sorta. The thing is is that I have become obsessed with the effect it provides. I?m able to function like a ?normal? person for the time being and that is something that I have always craved. The voice in my head that has never stopped has finally stopped, and god its like a breath of fresh air. The vibrating in my body slows and I can think. Today I had to skip my Adderall for medical reasons and all day I groaned to myself about how badly I needed it. I actually cried in class. Adderall has been my lord and savior but I?m addicted.

Ativan

This is also a prescription. It is from 2018 though. I suffered from crippling anxiety and this was prescribed to get my through the school day. The thing is is that I?m not supposed to be taking it anymore. But once an a while I take it for the euphoria. I?ve only done this a couple times but Ativan is nothing to play with. I?ve found myself craving it when nothing else is an option.

Summary: I?m not sure why I?m posting this. I know its really long, so if you didn?t read, I?m slightly addicted to a bunch of things. I think that each addiction developed as a coping mechanism from the previous, but I?m not sure. I know I need to get to the root of my pain and in turn, why I do this. I have a lot to figure out. I have a feeling that there are several mental illnesses that need a diagnosis. And I probably need some intense therapy to work though the horrendous childhood of mine. In the mean time it is terrifying growing up and watching myself throw everything away. I hope that this helped someone.

I like not having to think or feel. I don?t want to use my DOC but I don?t want to stop using other stuff. Every time I was shaking internally reminiscing about the past all the nostalgia coursing through my body. Of course I wouldn?t take her meds as she is crying in the next room? that isn?t me anymore. 2 long weeks of this. I kept my sobriety. Tonight she has 3.5 pills left sitting in the closet. She isn?t taking them anymore. That stupid orange bottle is like the eye of Mordor calling me. I know addiction is life long. So tonight I?ll take a deep breathe and remember how good the last 7 years have been, how I haven?t had to lie to doctors, deal with gang members or steal from medicine cabinets. I?ll take a really deep breathe and remember how since I have stopped abusing, I got married, bought a house and kept really good jobs.
I?ll take another really deep breathe and wake my wife and explain that I?m struggling and we need to get rid of them.

Someone once told me I would wake up one day and the sky would be bluer.

This was and is true.

I just didn?t think that sometimes the sky would feel heavy and dark.

Still? everyday has been worth it.

I (23f) have been an addict since I was 14. Started with benzos I was prescribed and codeine my mom had laying around. After 4 family and friend deaths, and a car accident that left me with brain damage and severe PTSD, I began abusing fentanyl and heroin. That was about two years ago now.

In August, I checked myself into rehab because my dealer robbed me and, honestly, I couldn't find another dealer and couldn't stand the withdrawals. I told them I got tired of living as an addict but it was a lie.

My family had NO idea I was an addict. Seriously. When my mom found out I was in rehab, she asked if it was adderall or something.

I was there for 8 weeks and they had me on suboxone. At the time of my discharge, I wanted to relapse right then. I didn't feel any better, despite doing everything they told me to do and trying my hardest. Meditation, praying (despite not believing in a higher power), nightly reviews, my fourth step. I did fucking prayer circles and everything. I really tried to find God.

So I essentially was white knuckling it for three months. Taking my suboxone, going to my appointments. I wasn't able to find a meeting that I liked, the only one within walking distance was all people 55+. They told me that I should find one with people my age. I started getting suicidal.

Last week, I got offered some fentanyl on facebook and now I'm using again. I feel guilty but I can't go through the pain of being sober anymore. Last night my mom hugged me and told me she's proud of me. I know I'm back right where I started and I should care more but mostly, I feel relief. Guilt, shame, but mostly relief.

About two months ago I went down the gambling rabbit hole reaaaal fast. I always like playing football bets every now and then. But in october 2021 online gambling was legalized here in The Netherlands. To be clear I never visited a real casini before. But online casino's made it easy for me to gamble from the comfort of my mancave chair. I always prefered blackjack in free online games. So that's what I settled on. I started small (30 euro's). Had a pretty decent start and then thought: 'if I can turn 30 euro's into 90 euro's, then I can turn 100 into 300'. Well folks, it turns out I was fucking wrong. In total I wasted 1500 to 2000 euro's in 3 weeks or so. At a certain point it completely took over my mind. Especially when shit in personal life or work life got rough I got the craving to gamble. It was my way to deflect feeling shit. Turns out it was also my way to feel even shittier. My mind was constantly occupied with the number 21. I even gambled at work when the day was slow. My mood was completely bound to winning or losing. My god if I look back now I realise how awful it was. I also recall feeling completely hazed. At one point I thought: 'enough is enough' and found out I can self-exclude through our national gambling commission. This really killed it for me. Literally no more ways (except sketchy illegal shit) for me to gamble. Today I had a shit day at work and boy did I long for a pair of queens. But that's not the way to face a tough day. Work through it and don't avoid stuff. Really check if you can ban yourself from casino's / online casino's. It's a big step,but going cold turkey is the way. Find something else you enjoy, learn to play an instrument, get into excercising, go join a drama group. Anything really, but don't be a dopamine zombie like I was.

im Maria im 73 days sober and I think I'm gonna relapse. I really wanted to write out the reason why, so that it's on record somewhere in the depths of the internet. It all started when my friend introduced me to blow, and I have bpd- so if you're my favorite person at the time, we in it together. My friend is bipolar so he flew off the rails way before I did, got proper treatment and all, super proud of him. But I was just getting started. It kinda culminated when my friends boyfriend (a drug dealer) kinda integrated our friend group over summer 2021. I've got crazy FOMO, as the pandemic started I was 18, I never went clubbing or partying like crazy... I felt so behind, both socially and academically. I just wanted to catch up so bad. And my friends boyfriend (let's call him Enoch) would sell me snow to my heart's content. Soon he'd start giving me shit for free... Fast forward a few months, Enoch and his girl open up the relationship, and Enoch starts seeing Sevan (I know it's a guy's name but trust me Sev's a chick). Sevan and I meet when Enoch offers to smoke me out, at this point Im living on my own downtown, and it turns out me and sev go to the same school. We hit it off super well but Enoch makes it a point to mention to me and sev he won't give me drugs anymore. I'll find out later that Enoch will say anything to look good, but will rarely actually act on it. Me and sev start dating- like there's any way this will end well- considering Enoch was also dating her and Enoch was my best friend at the time. It was about to get hella messy. Mid October 2021 I relapse, Enoch gives me a shitton of snow for free. Sevan is bewildered, giving me ultimatums. At this point I was justifying my addiction in any way I could, so I got away with it somehow. Eventually Sevan broke up with Enoch and then me (she had the courtesy to meet Enoch over lunch but I got broken up w over text), I tell Enoch about it. It is a Monday night, I'm drunk off my ass. Enoch had just spent a few days in the psych ward, heads over to my place without telling me a thing. Of course we fucked. The motherfucker had feelings for me this whole time, and upon hearing me vulnerable and drunk, he jumps at the opportunity to "comfort me". Although Enoch and his girlfriend were open, they had agreed I was off limits, and that this was officially cheating. Enoch agrees to tell his girlfriend the truth as I head to class. I'm panicking, I puke on my way to class, I leave class early cuz I'm so out of it and Enoch WAS STILL IN MY APPARTMENT. I tell him I need some space- and he says he's gonna go for a drive. And sure he does: he goes missing for three days. This is when I find out about the psych ward, about his mom starting chemo (yes he stole his mom's car as she was starting chemo, I can't make this shit up). Everyone thought he was dead. Enoch had a history with suicidal ideation. His mom texts me, and I find out he's missing, and I think "oh my god he's dead because of me, I'll have to go to a funeral and pretend I don't know why he killed himself". And I realised what I had to do... I tell his girlfriend the truth. The cops found him a few days later, and all he had to say was "I didn't start it" to his gf to give her all the info she needed. Obviously I lost two of my closest friends. They're still together though. Oh and after I got clean, I managed to stay friends with Sevan, but I kept getting the ick- knowing she was still friends w Enoch. Now it was my turn to give her the ultimatum, him or me. She chose him. Now I've survived the worst of it. Now after all this how can I even consider relapsing?? Well, I dropped out after all that, cuz my head wasn't working so well, and I had to move back into my parents house. It's two years later since March 2020 but I'm reliving the same day over and over again, and I've got but more of this tartarian expanse waiting for me for the next year. Perhaps if I relapse I'll prove to myself that the damage Enoch did was irreparable. Unforgivable. As if by relapsing, I'll be taking my revenge on those who hurt me. I have things going for me but, Im so scared of living.

Context: I'm 26 years old. On paper I'm successful and run a really cool company that presumably would make me good money and live a good life.

Since 18 I've been a raging gambling addict. I was cursed by winning a ton of money early, like six figures over a sustained period of time, and thinking I was a professional. I wanted my life to be either professional sports betting or analytics based on my sports betting prowess. I chose my major at a top university based off of it and even made presentations to large classes at request of professors in college about how good I was at gambling. By the end of college not only had I lost hundreds of thousands of dollars and was destitute broke, but I was also a bookie who was betting against his own book and was under threat by people with heavy mob ties for owing tens of thousands of dollars. I played hardball with them, risked the wellbeing of people I cared by calling bluffs on threats and eventually they left me alone because the nature of the business I started in 2017 made it too risky for them to go after me. In those years, I lost hundreds and hundreds of thousands of dollars gambling. I was an early investor in cryptocurrency, and bet with crypto almost exclusively. Not that this matters, but those losses in present value are easily $10 million of Bitcoin, maybe more.

I got to almost three years of clean time from 2018-2021 before I relapsed after the GameStop craze here on reddit sucked me in. Thought I'd just make a quick couple day trade, ride the wave and get out. My bank account was up to $70,000 of hard-earned money, by far the best it had ever been, it had been so long since I had gambled that I was sure it was a thing of the past, and I "had a few grand to play around with". One trade of GameStop and before I knew it I had lost 50 or 60 grand in a month (I realized my GME losses pretty quick, wasn't joining that cult, lost 20-30 grand more sports betting) and was back to square one.

Depression over this pathetic relapse led me to start smoking weed and taking drugs again. I have a serious allergy to weed called Cannabinoid Hyperemesis Syndrome where weed can literally kill you. After a three month bender of weed and many other drugs, toiling in the depression of losing all my money, I checked myself into rehab and got sober July 10th 2021.

Fast forward to this past weekend. I've had a few gambling lapses the past month, like losing a few hundred here and there. Basically been consciously throwing out long shots every now and then to try and get lucky and make a few grand to pad my bank account. I'm living with my parents, after living in a beautiful NYC apartment from 2019-2021. I've been here since August. I'm finally getting into a situation where I've been looking at some (albeit shitty) apartments in Brooklyn. I think I got triggered by this and on Friday I deposited $500 into a bitcoin spots book.

I turned $500 into $5000 in about 15 bets over a 2 day period. I withdrew a grand every time I won, telling myself this was the gambling god's last gift to me, and that I'd keep going heavy until the hot streak ended. Once I lost a bet, I promised myself, I'd have this newfound money that I'd withdrawn into my bank account, and call it a career.

I forgot that you never stop until you're not up anymore.

24 hours ago I was up $5,700. For the situation I've been in the past year, that is life-changing money. I had withdrawn $3,500 of that into my bank account. I put $2,200 on the Australian Open Championship last night, and lost in brutal fashion in a six hour match that kept me up until 9 AM Eastern Time. I managed to hold my word for about 20 minutes. Next thing I knew I put $500 back into the site for one last hoorah. Next thing I know it's another grand because that bet lost. Next thing I know it's another $1,500. And now here we are, 24 hours later, and my bank account is almost zero.

I am so ashamed of myself because I feel like I have already learned enough of these lessons to be wise beyond my years. And it makes me almost mourn for myself like I have something broken in my brain that will never be fixed. I'm doing ok in my sobriety from drugs (living in a small house with my parents who know about my issues helps), but I am just so incredibly depressed and angry at myself. I just bought myself months more of the shame of living with my parents, not being able to get out into a place of my own.

Though many look at me as successful and even inspirational because I hide my flaws from all but my close friends and family, and am somewhat of a public figure, I look at myself right now and see the biggest fucking loser I know.

Hopefully someone who went through something similar can provide some perspective. A lot of times, you'll see people talking about "I just want to experience the joy and happiness I had before I started using" or "go back to before I relapsed, when I was so happy and joyful."

I do not relate to that at all. For me, really the only true, absolutely amazing happiness I have ever experienced was through substances. Everything else, family memories, times with friends, doesn't even come close to comparing. I've been "in recovery" with a relapse here and there for 2 years. Currently living in a halfway house and moving out in a few months to my parents so I can save money for an apartment. After that, my plan is to just work, come home and smoke weed, and rinse and repeat.

The things I enjoy besides doing drugs are video games, pagan spirituality, and playing/writing heavy metal music, all things that the Christian halfway house I'm in frowns upon, as well as my parents. This makes it very awkward for me to go and seek out people who share the same interests, as the House manager and my parents will want to know what I'm up to and dissuade me from it. So, I try to stay in my room as much as possible and not interact with anyone. If I can get by without saying one word to another person IRL in a day, I consider it a victory. I have no idea whether I'm an introvert or extrovert, but I genuinely cannot stand being around people in recovery at all anymore, repeating the same shit over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over again-- the quotes from the rooms, pithy non-denominational Christian sayings, talking about how blessed they are to be given the opportunity to be in a halfway house.

I used to have very high aspirations, but I've come to realize they're all nonsense. It took everything in my power to meditate, read spiritual literature, and engage in intellectually stimulating conversation everyday for 3 months, and it still didn't even come close to providing the relief and happiness that a bowl of weed does. I've tried therapy; planning on dipping my toes back in, but my anxiety and need for the therapist to like me prevent me from unloading my true anger, misanthropy, and frustration, so I end up just self-analyzing in the room with them for an hour and getting a worksheet that I rarely complete. Honestly, I just want someone to be able to look me in the eye after hearing every single one of my disgusting, hateful thoughts and seeing the worst of me and say, "I love you and like being around you." Even more than that, I desperately want to be able to believe them.

This post has turned into more of a rambling ventpost, so my apologies for that. Hopefully someone sees it and can relate and give me some guidance.

I know it's a bit long, but I want to, as briefly as I can, share my story and experiences with you all, as well as being glad I got through these things, so that I can now celebrate and be proud of my small achievements.

Just for a quick back story... I had a pretty rubbish upbringing, divorced parents, a toxic relationship with my father and step mother, bullied at school, no friends, diagnosed with various mental illnesses at 12 years old and in and out of mental health services/social services till I was 18...

In 2014, just after my 18th birthday, I entered a 4 year long relationship with a man who physically, sexually and emotionally abused me for the whole time, we had a child together, who I lost custody of and haven't seen since they were 2 years old.

I left the relationship at 2018 when I was just turning 23, I moved in with my mum, and even though we had quite a toxic relationship while I was growing up, I think not seeing me or speaking to me for four years during my abusive relationship, worrying about how I was being treated and not knowing whether I would end up dead, completely changed her and changed how she was towards me and it also changed how I was towards her, as me and my mum have always mirrored eachother and brought out the best and worst of eachother and during those four years, we both changed and grew a lot as people ...

But a year or so down the line, mine and my mum's relationship broke down which resulted in me becoming homeless. Not only was I suffering badly with my mental health, (PTSD, DID/personality disorder, psycosis and depression) but I had also just quit my job and had no money, I wasn't speaking to my dad so couldn't stay with him and I became homeless during the beginning of the pandemic, so not only was I at risk of catching covid, but I couldn't go and stay with my Nan, who was probably the one person that would have had me live with her rather than being on the streets.

I ended up, thankfully, being put into temporary accommodation and also had the pleasure of meeting my fianc, who I have been with for nearly two years now, but on the downside, my addiction got a lot worse and a lot heavier and my mental health was at its very worst, especially as I had no therapy or counselling for the previous domestic abuse and I was still dealing with the pain and trauma of all of this alone.

Then December 2020, at 2am, I was physically assaulted in my local high street, and never recovered mentally from this

My addiction had improved so much before this had happened, I was on Espranor (which is like subutex) and had cut down my use massively, but after this incident, I fell straight back down that dark hole of allowing myself to be cuddled and cared for by drugs and just numbing the thoughts and the pain that came to me everyday.

Since then, I haven't left the house really... Out of the 365 days in the year, I had probably spent about 50 of those, properly outside of the house and that's it, I have to go to my pharmacy everyday and go to mental health appointments every two weeks, but that's as much as I can cope with..

I spent most days in bed, watching TV or flicking through social media because I cannot physically get out of bed, I just have a complete block, my brain won't allow me to do anything else, I'll stand up and prep myself, "right, screw this, I'm going for a walk" and instantly my body will respond with, "ooft, I'm feeling absolutely exhausted, I can barely keep my eyes open, my legs hurt, I need to lay down and sleep".

I completely let myself go.

I will go days without washing or brushing my teeth, I won't cook for myself or eat proper meals, instead I'll spend my day eating a few packets of crisps/chips, a microwave hotdog, crackers with butter/soft cheese, yoghurts, chocolate, brownies etc, I won't tidy up my flat or wash the dishes, I barely do any laundry (which I don't really need to do anyway because I'll either wear the same tracksuit bottoms and jumper all week or just wear my PJs), I'll ignore all my phone calls, ignore my partner, not show any affection and be completely selfish.

Occasionally, I'll have 2 or 3 days where I'm full of energy and motivation and self love, I'll have a shower and a shave, wash my hair, brush my teeth, pamper myself by wearing a face mask, doing my nails, I'll put on nice clothes, go to the pharmacy, do some shopping, take a walk, cook some nice food, be affectionate and attentive to my partner, give my flat a spring clean, do all my laundry, and then bam! After those couple of days, I'm back to being stuck in bed.

I ended up getting put onto regular medication, anti psycotics, anti depressants and sleeping pills, which allowed me to get control of my addiction again, as I no longer needed to numb my feelings and emotions, as the medication was balancing everything, as my drug use has always mostly been an attempt to self medicate, I no longer needed to give myself my own treatment, as I was now getting stuff that was doing a good enough job, but then later on in the year, the doctor decided to take me off of everything, saying my mental health was drug induced and completely disregarding the multiple diagnosis' that I have, the 4 years of domestic abuse that I'd been through, disregarding the fact that I've had multiple mental issues since I was pretty much born and have had these issues long before I started doing drugs and disregarding that I was using drugs to self medicate BECAUSE I wasn't getting any treatment for my mental health in the first place. So because of the Doctors wonderful and helpful choice, again, I have gone back to allowing illicit drugs to numb my pain and help me ignore my problems rather than actually facing and/or dealing with anything.

So...At the beginning of this year, I decided that if I'm not going to go out, I need to make being inside, fun, productive, positive and happy, so I figured I would firstly:

1.Practice self love and self care by keeping up with my hygiene more often, I wouldn't push myself and force myself to shower everyday, for example, but perhaps have a shower every other day, or every couple of days. 2.I would then take pride in my appearance and also dye my hair and keep up with maintaining the colour, as usually I will dye my hair and then leave it to fade and let the roots come through and not touch it again for another six months, but now I've decided to always keep my hair looking pretty and presentable, touching up my roots and colour constantly or changing the colour regularly rather than letting it fade. 3.On some days I will dress myself in nice clothes, even if I am only just going to the pharmacy or just going food shopping, I will put on a proper outfit rather than wearing sweats all week 4.I also plan to pay more attention to my partner and if I'm feeling withdrawn and don't want to be affectionate because I'm feeling bad, I will tell him this rather than just ignoring him and I will also work on communicating better and be more open about how I'm feeling 5.But most importantly, I decided to take up 3 hobbies which I plan to dedicate myself to, get good at and hopefully, turn my hobby into a business.

I've started knitting, crochet, and model making/sculpting with clay. I've knitted and used clay before, I have a basic knowledge of each, but stopped doing these things after s few years and decided I'm going to give them a go again and not give up this time, but I am learning how to crochet for the first time ever.

I struggle to dedicate myself to hobbies because I have a low attention span and get bored of things quickly and also give up as soon as the product or result of what I do isn't "good enough", I have a perfectionist mindset and expect to be a professional at something, the first time I try it and give up if it's not at a perfect standard first time, but I can say, with pride, that I have stuck to these things and motivating myself to practice and practice and keep getting good. I have a goal in my mind and this time I'm determined to reach it.

Being stuck in the flat for the last two years has made me feel like a failure and a waste of space, I'm not contributing anything to the world or society, I'm not socialising with anyone and I started to feel like my existence was pointless as I'm not doing any good for anyone and just being selfish and living in my own world, isolating myself from everyone. Because of this, it sparked my idea to start documenting my journey with my mental health and addiction and allow people to follow me on my path.

Spending a lot of time alone has also made me think about how everything online is so edited and how everything is portrayed in a way that people's lives are perfect and happy and people's appearances are also portrayed the same, so when people like me go online, we feel depressed, envious, insecure, because our lives are often sad and depressing, we go through a lot of trauma, most of the time we don't look our best or don't dress our best and we feel like failures because our lives aren't the same as the ones we see online, this thought has made me want to show people the honest reality of my life. I had the intention to show people that life isn't always perfect and that we can always look sexy and beautiful, that it's completely normal to stay in bed all week and not shower for a couple of days. (I know I discussed the potential of doing something like this with some of you, but I am fully embracing and dedicating myself to the idea now, thanks to all of the positive responses I got from everyone, so thanks to you all for that)

Doing this, like my hobbies, is another way for me to escape and live a fulfilling life and doing this will make me feel like I have purpose again, and that I'm not just a waste of life and energy because it will give me the opportunity to positively affect people's lives and potentially help, support and guide people as well as helping others to feel like they're not alone and that there are people in the world that understand how they feel and experience the same things as them.

As well as all of these positive ideas that I have thought of, which will hopefully improve my life and my mental health, I have finally been seen by a psychologist and starting trauma therapy in the next month... This will be the first time since experiencing domestic abuse that I will be addressing the trauma and pain caused by that situation, which will hopefully help me to move on and potentially, will be the key to getting me out of my bed permenantly and help lead me back out into the world again and give me the tools to care for and look after myself.

Even though I'm restricted because of my mental health and these last 8 years of my life have been traumatic and painful, things are slowly and steadily moving in a good and positive direction and I want to share this and celebrate this with you today ..

Anyway.... hes drastically thrown himself into alcoholism since his father passed 3 years ago. Identity Transitions Survey
Have you experienced an identity transition, moving from one identity to another, becoming at least in some respect a different person than the one who existed before? Becoming a parent, getting a divorce, retiring, moving to a new country, gender transitioning, becoming a veteran, battling addiction, and many other life experiences can change our sense of self and affect many aspects of our everyday life.

If you have experienced an identity transition, please consider participating in this survey. This research will help to better understand the domains of one's life impacted by identity transitions and explore how to help people to better navigate these experiences. The survey will take between 10-15 minutes to complete and you can either fill it out anonymously or supply an email address for the chance to win one of five $50 gift cards and/or participate in future research for compensation. You must be 18 years old to participate.

Has anyone been addicted to people / others needs - so that i would be liked / loved (also another way to avoid thinking my stuff) - Now - i dont have a good sense who i like as i have limited sense of self. ....
One weird thing that i came to realise and am now working through - i was addicted to people. Focusing on others needs and their wants, and just going over and above for others so that i could feel cared for and loved (although i appreciate that now). I had zero boundaries and would make so much effort for others. I also would get annoyed that others didnt reciprocate but i didnt share that for fear of rejection.

I recall doing this as a teen in dating but also doing it as an adult in friendships also - i make it easy for people to be friends with me as i am always messaging and wanting to hand. However i just dont have a sense of who i am and why i am friends with a lot of people, i just had to escape myself ( did that with addictions also).

Like I'm hungry and will never have food again.
That is how I behave in terms of my addiction. I smoke like chain smoking chimpanzee. It's like a second nature.. like I'll never be satisfied or full. It's like I'm starving and can't get full. I drink after work daily, again like I can't fill up, I down 4 beers in the first 30 minutes. All day I count the minutes until it's time to drink. I count the minutes until my next smoke.

Its impulse control. It's this sense of needing more no matter how much I've had. And the inability to have the discipline to slow down. I literally just had a cigarette and I already want another.

How do you get yourself to a place where your mind and body isn't screaming for more? Or have some sort of sense being satisfied.

KJ 2022

This leads me to a black hole spirling with late nights, monotone thoughts and the urge to find peacefulness elsewhere.
