I?m not sure where I could post this but? I?ve been with my boyfriend for about a year and I never saw a problem with my weed consumption. I was about a year clean when we first met but after a couple months I become very depressed. I had a lot going on at home and at school. I was just exhausted and drained all the time. I decided to start smoking again just to get high. The first couple of times I started using it again was just for fun. But then it got to the point where I started using it when i was having a bad day or just needed to get rid of some stress. I never saw it as a problem because I didn?t do this on a daily basis and used it as a way to get ?help?. I would only do it every once in a while. For example, i would smoke every weekend or every other week. It did help me a lot. It made me feel calm and euphoric. And I loved that feeling. Every time I would get high I would call my boyfriend and we would just talk and fall asleep together and I liked that. Unfortunately, one of the times I smoked I had a really bad trip which caused me to hyperventilate for a long time(i dont know how long I don?t remember much from this night). But I do remember being scared that I was gonna die (even tho you can?t OD on weed). When this happened I was otp with my boyfriend. He was scared and worried about me. Basically, I left him traumatized. I didn?t know this because he didn?t really tell me. So I kept smoking despite of that. My boyfriend had opened up about how he felt about me smoking and expressed to me that he didn?t like it and that I should probably stop. I told him I would stop so I did. I was clean for maybe 3 months or so. But round October 2021 I got in a big argument with my dad and he ended up hitting me and kicking me out. And within the same week of this happening, I had found out that my boyfriend had been lying and hiding things from me. Basically, he made a secret TikTok account just so he can look at girls, he had many porn accounts, and was basically addicted to porn. This made me upset because during our whole relationship he told me he didn?t watch porn and that he would never follow girls or look at them like that because he ?respected? me. He also knew how I felt about this. I relapsed because of these two things. But I didn?t tell him. He promised to me that he would be better and stop lying and hiding things from me. So I promised him I would stop smoking. I was fine until mid December when I found out that he was still doing the same behavior. He also told me that he masturbated to girls from his school, his own cousin, possibly gore(???), and much more disturbing things. This really fucked with me. I would always think about the things he did to me and said to me. He lied to me twice about it, both times promising he would be better. I couldn?t get the girls out of my head. I would constantly compare myself to them and when he would compliment me I didn?t believe him because clearly I wasn?t his type. This would be all I think about 24/7. I would lose my appetite, not eat, and feel sick about this. I was disappointed and infuriated about this. So I said fuck it. I need to smoke. So I relapsed. I relapsed the beginning of this month and wow. I feel like sometimes weed/drugs aren?t as bad as people make it seem. I felt calm, my mind was blank, I felt peace. For the first time in months. I felt amazing. It really helped me. It made me forget about everything he did. I didn?t tell him about this time either. I felt amazing. When I woke up the next day I really felt like a whole new person. I woke up feeling content with who I was and I felt happy with myself. I was able to forget about the girls and all which really helped. Unfortunately, just a couple days ago I had confessed to him and told him about the day I relapsed and he was very upset with me. He thinks I have a problem or an addiction because every time I would get upset the first thing that would come to mind is ?I need to smoke? or ?I wish I was high?. He also thought this was a problem because of the fact that I kept doing it and lying to him and manipulating him (I didn?t realize I did). At first I refused to believe this because of the fact that I didn?t do it everyday. And I did it because I needed help and I felt like I had no one. Him and I had an argument yesterday because of this. I told him the it was his fault I relapsed. He didn?t let me explain to him on how I had been feeling and the main reason I relapsed. He lied to me and basically cheated on me. He?s in active recovery about this. But he gave me an ultimatum. Him or drugs. I honestly didn?t know which one I wanted to choose. So he said if I wasn?t willing to try and get better he would leave me. So my question is do I have a problem? If so how can I do better. I don?t have access to a therapist because of money problems but I?m willing to try my best with what I got. I just don?t wanna break up with him even tho after what he did I did see a lot of growth in him when he actually started to be better. Anyway though, what can I do.

What will help me pass my urine test for benzodiazepines. Baking soda and vinegar can help? I take klonopin 2mg daily for a month. Im not able to use quick fix because someone is watching me doing it. Adding few drops visine or bleach can help? Pls help me its important.

Man my emotions are skyrocketed in whichever direction they choose. Being 19 is a part of it but my adhd and anxiety and depression play a big role too.

But despite being in active addiction, today I was sober at work and felt great. I was being jokative and funny and talkative with everyone, which is how I normally am wout drugs. I felt confident and motivated and balanced. Just out of nowhere.

This type of day is extremely rare for me and most days are spent in misery and depression, lethargy, constant constant relapses, numbing myself, being selfish, etc. But fuck man... fuck. You think I would want to keep this going and just free myself from drugs and show up sober in a clear head the next day like myself even better. But that's not the case tonight, even when I have to wake up early tommorow and want to be able to be my normal energetic goofball of energy I am lol. I seem to be able to recover from addiction so quickly probably due to young age but the boredom gets sooooo nagging to me I quickly revert to my old ways everytime. I know this sounds immature but somehow this boredom becomes a void for me and after work I have nothing to fill it besides drugs and pleasurable stimulating and usually unhealthy activities. Seems if I have money and a way I will always keep going back to this junk. I don't understand. Don't even know why I'm posting this. Just randomly wanted to share my thoughts because I am lost. Even when I have my good days I keep myself down in a low state lower than I thought low could get.

After I get from work I spent the day on my PC playing games, watching movies, TV shows, anime and so on, and stay on my PC till late at night and do the same cycle every day.

I am not a kid anymore I have more responsibilities, and I am ignoring them by using my computer.

I think that what you enjoy is not a bless but a curse. But I don't know how to change myself my gaming/ entertainment life is very important to me.

Weed addiction is real.
From around grade 9 to grade 11 in high school I was very addicted to marijuana.

Everyday when I would come home from school I would smoke in order to forgot the shitty life I was living. I wasn?t smoking in groups of people like normal high school potheads, but instead I would do it by my self for the main purpose of forgetting about my horrible social life. The main reason I would do this is is because of my horrible anxiety I had while in school. I just got so paranoid being around other people in certain situations and instead of thinking about how I could fix myself I would instead get high. It got so rough that instead I was only happy when high off of marijuana. When high I just felt a sense of enjoyment, a feeling that I would not get while sober.

Something that I want kids in that may see this post is to live high school like nobody is watching you or judging you, don?t get so wound up anxiety that you have no social life because of it. Also I suggest to not smoke marijuana by yourself because it can easily and quickly become a coping method for depression.

Addicted to someone who no longer loves me.
First off, I apologize if this isn't the appropriate sub for this. I'm absolutely addicted to a person who has little to no feelings for me and I don't know how to put an end to it. When I say addicted, I mean that I check their activity status dozens of times a day to see what they are playing, or listening to, or if they've followed anyone new, etc. I reread our old sappy conversations trying to feel happy but it's bittersweet. I can't do hardly anything without it reminding me of them in some way or another, whether it's a good memory or a bad one.

We used to be together - we've known each other for about 3 years, been together for ~2. We were both overly attached and possessive of the other and decided it would be better to break up, but remain a bit more than friends (cuddling and the like). We stopped being together over 6 months ago. Things were going very well but in the last two months they have gotten distant. We stopped seeing each other for the past two months because they come from a big household of unvaccinated individuals and I didn't want to risk carrying covid to my dad, who I live with.

We used to tell each other "I love you" often and that doesn't happen anymore. They say they have been majorly depressed and want to be isolated from everyone, so I've been trying my best to not message them or otherwise bug them. But I can't shake this fear that they don't want me anymore, when I ask if they want what we have they just say "I don't know".

I don't know how to stop myself from obsessing over this person. I think what makes it all the more painful is that they told me it was really cute that I cared so much that I would check their profile so often and was so needy for them. I highly doubt they still feel that way. I can't stand the thought of them falling for someone else. On top of it all, my life has gone to shit recently and I need their support now more than ever. I know that sounds selfish but I really don't know what else to do. Talking to friends just isn't the same.

Wow. 25 days clean today. I spent the last almost 5 years slowly beginning to lose my grasp on the progressive disease of addiction. I've been given an incredible gift, another chance to live life on life's terms. I got so, so close to rock bottom. Somehow I had just enough self-awareness to look at how much further I had to fall and recognize that this is the time to stop.

I grew up LDS (Mormon), and I pushed away really hard. Organized religion is not for me, nor was any higher power for most of my life. I've wanted to stop for a long time, I've known that I had a problem. I tried NA and I had these roadblocks that I could identify, but couldn't get past. I got a sponsor, I really tried, but I couldn't stay clean for more than a week. Surrender was so difficult for me; I couldn't figure out how to accept there was a benevolent higher power. I gave up, I decided I could just be a better addict.

It got worse, naturally. I overdosed, should've died. I got lucky. My mom had a hunch for some reason, cops came over to my apartment for a welfare check. I was still just barely coherent enough to let them in. I had almost an ounce of meth in separate bags, fentanyl, a scale, benzos, a bunch of thc carts. I wasn't selling, but it sure as hell looked like it. They didn't charge me because I was cooperative, took me to the ER. Ended up in the BHU, they assumed it was an attempted suicide.

I don't think I'll ever forget the moment it finally all clicked for me. I was getting ready to start trying to manipulate the therapist there so I could get out ASAP and go back to what I was doing. But for some reason I decided to take a step back and just look at my life. I had been miserable for so long. This is one of 4 overdoses, 3 of which happened in the last year. I'm gonna fucking die. Do I really want to die? That's where I'm headed, I can only get lucky so many times. I had a scholarship to school, a girlfriend of 5 years, a nice apartment, a pretty good job. Lost it all. And I just finally surrendered.

I still don't believe in God, but I can now flip the switch in my brain that denies the existence of a higher power. NA just started working for me. I spent the next week cleaning out my apartment, packing a single suitcase with clothes and I moved to another state. I'm going into a rehab facility in 10 days. I finally figured it out, and I'm so grateful to everyone that got me here. I wouldn't change a single fucking thing that happened. I get to draw on those experiences for the rest of my life. My parents, my girlfriend that enabled me, my using friends, hell my dealers; Thanks for the ride. It's time for a personality change.

Relapse caused heavy psychosis
A little bit of background on me: I was addicted to stimulants since I was 15, and binged a lot. I quit a year ago and had been sober since. I have schizoaffective disorder, which is like bipolar and schizophrenia mixed. It causes a lot of psychosis. I also have ptsd from sexual assaults.

I decided to smoke a little bit of weed thinking it would be harmless about two months ago. Then without me noticing that I was falling back into my old habits, I smoked every night so I could feel better. I got back home after visiting my parents and smoked some weed with my partner. It triggered a five hour long episode of psychosis and PTSD flashbacks. It was excruciatingly terrifying. My entire body was shaking and I could hear millions of voices threatening me.

I?m fine now, and I haven?t smoked weed since. I?m just really upset at myself and guilty for relapsing. It was so hard for me to quit stimulants, and now I have to go through the whole process again. I?m really upset with myself. Also, I knew the dangers of smoking weed with my diagnosis, but I recklessly did it anyway. I?m ashamed. I don?t know what to do.

Thoughts are just rolling off the tip of my fingers here, but please stick with me. Addiction started at 15 born fast forward 15 years. I have many resources in addiction, at 17 methadone I was put on methadone, and benzodiazepines I stayed clean for five years and was a normal guy, to some degree..

2015 my addiction came back full blown I started using again with things to cut threw the mmat treatment since then things haven't been the same. I quit the union and decided to go back to being a full time addict. Multiple rehab attempts and failed detoxs things are finally starting to stick my periods of sobriety are now getting longer while uses become shorter.

I have never had a first hand experience with substance use disorder or addiction. I have watched many loved ones suffer with this illness and it has hurt me greatly.

To make a long story short and give as little detail as possible, for therapy for the sake of my healing I had to write a letter to the addict in my life who is currently in the first few months of recovery. It feels selfish to even write this letter because I want their recovery to come first but at the same time, I?m hoping that it helps me and my loved one. I know people with addiction are most likely aware of how they hurt the ones who love them but while addicts suffer, their friends and family also suffer immensely. Maybe more than people realize.

I?m feeling really nervous about this letter because I don?t want to say anything that is insensitive or makes it sound like I am putting myself first. I want to get across all the ways that I have been hurt but also make it clear that I know that it is not this person?s fault. While they have hurt me so badly, I will still be here for every step of their recovery.

I?m wondering if anyone will be kind enough to be willing to basically proof read this for me and make sure I am being courteous and aware of their suffering while also making my points clear. I could send it in a PM and edit out names or personal info. I don?t want to say anything that will be harmful to their recovery. I will warn you first, the letter is long and depressing but writing it has helped a bit and I think them reading it would help me even more.

A little about me... 35 year old male relativity successful with regards to work running my own business, married last September and a one year old daughter which im very proud and happy about, on the face of it my life is great but i have a problem and my problem is cocaine. I have noticed in particular over the past 2/3 years things are starting to become out of control (or even more out of control). Previously a friday into Saturday would be my norm 1-3g depending what I had planned. Now it can be fri/sat/sun and midweek even during work. I seem to find any excuse to use ie. footballs on lets get a bag.... tested positive for Covid lets get a bag (no joke very shameful).

I have an association with alcohol and coke which I cant deny, right now to me they are one and the same if I drink I snort simple as that which means for the foreseeable future no alcohol. I am a little confused as to what my problem is... is both only the coke or is it alcohol? I have an understanding of being addicted to Alcohol as both my parents are recovering alcoholic's both been in recovery for over 28 years. I suppose in a way I'm ashamed that history is/has repeated itself and its something I was determined not to allow to happen. Due to this i haven't spoken to my parents on this subject as it feels completely shameful and i have let them down........ does anyone have any advice having this discussion with loved ones/parents?

I am currently 19days without using cocaine and about 10 of alcohol which I'm delighted with, have spoken with my wife and have her support, going to the gym 4/5 times a week all of which is really helping me and keeping me focused, long term im hoping I can maintain this although I have an uneasy feeling about cravings and working through them.... esp out with friends whist drunk as coke is freely available and in abundance. Again any useful help or advice on this or anything else would be greatly received and much apricated.

He's been an addict on and off for many years. He is not my biological brother, but was raised with me as such, essentially. As a teenager, he moved in with my alcoholic mother and I during a period he was struggling with his use. My mom left me with lots of PTSD always worrying about her ODing, and my brother did too (frequently nodding out in the bathroom to the point of being unresponsive, but not overdosed). My mom passed earlier this year, and Ive been on a long and difficult journey to work through my trauma from life since. My brother showed up unannounced three days ago at 2 am, homeless and needing a safe place. I took him in and have helped him get the basics (showered, fed, clean clothes). Its day three, and I was able to get him to go help my grandmother for money, and only now sitting alone do I feel the decompression and stress coming off. I felt like I was disassociated and in a trance while he was here; I trade stocks and crypto and I was making terrible choices and not using my proper trading tools I know I have, lost 30% in the three days from not managing my risk appropriately. A small example, but I feel that Im so occupied by trying to keep calm and use my DBT skills to avoid having a PTSD episode that I cannot function in the ways I need to do be both productive and content. I suffer from chronic depression among other issues, and building/taking part in a "life worth living" is essential to keep the worst of my symptoms at bay. Productivity is a large part of this for me.

I love my brother so much, however, we both have had hard lives and Im still doing my best to get my stuff sorted out, alone, at 22. I have no family support outside of my grandmother, and she is not well off and helps with things like extra food and basic supplies if I cant manage due to bills. I missed a shift at work the next morning because i didn't know what kind of mindset he was in, and many people who know addicts also know addiction can drive people to make morally unaligned choices; with a history of stealing, I couldnt risk having what little I have taken from me by him, let alone knowing the negative emotional impact it would have also had on him to betray me (hes a very caring person). I barely slept the past few days, always monitoring his breathing when hes nodding off on my couch. It's just too much for me at this moment to have him staying with me, although he made it clear he wasn't trying to move in, and that he just needed a place to stay for a moment (happy to house him, hate to know my family is struggling).

I know I have to have the conversation with him addressing why he can't live here (out of respect for him, hes my family and deserves that understanding imo), but I feel like I need to have a conversation that lets him know that 1) I love him 2) I want to see him get help (all senses; not just addiction) 3) I want to see him do well 4) Im too young and going through too much of my own stuff to have the stress of seeing him daily in this condition, while he also needs my emotional and logical support figuring out how to navigate his situation.

Hello. I am 31 years old, and went through a pretty bad meth and crack addiction for about 3 years. I lost a lot in my addiction, such as a good job and my apartment. I'm currently living in a halfway house and have a job again. I have a little over 90 days clean now. It's still a struggle. I would say my life is definitely more stable and structured. I'm eating and sleeping regularly. My life is far from amazing though, and my problems are not going to magically disappear because I'm clean. A part of me still misses the "rush" of the drugs (and the sex lol). I also found the chaos of active addiction kind of exciting. Am I the only one feeling this way? I've experienced many beautiful moments being in recovery, but there is that part of me that still wants to use. I also have a rebellious side to me, so conforming to American societal standards of being a "responsible" adult is difficult for me. I don't know.... Sorry for the long post. Thanks for any thoughts on this.

I decided to daily log my attempt at going cold turkey off nicotine. I plan to be sharing this every day and adding to the daily log to have people hold me accountable.

Day 1 of quitting nicotine:

I feel the most insane cravings I ever have. My body has been brought into a constant state of hyperactivity and awareness, however I compete actions at maybe 75% the accuracy I wish too. I have gone threw 10 peices of gum(and counting) and have developed a shake in my hands that's absolutely brutal. I've been told I look exhausted by several coworkers however I feel grossly awake, as if my eyes are crawling out of my head. I form sentences but not insightful responses that I wish too with people. I have touched my face 100+ times, but consistently feel unsatisfied. Going to the gym to attempt to obliterate my body and get some good rest to suffer again tomorrow.

Although that's somber asf I'm actually quiet enthusiastic about quiting and going strong!

Ive been playing video games fairly regularly since I was probably about 15. I am now 38, and far from being over it I still find that if I have "free" time that I spend it playing games.

I try to structure my day so that I get a few jobs out the way and get to the Gym or out for exercise, but at the end of the day I realise I'm actually structuring that day around time playing games. It doesn't get in the way of work particularly, but I am at a stage in my life where I am getting over the midway point and I really don't want to look back on my life and think I spent it hunched over a computer moving pixels around for some kind of hypnotic boredom suppressant. This is essentially how I spent my university years. Looking back at it I can't help but think I totally wasted that period when I could have been out making friends and meeting girls I was just sat on my own.

I guess the reason I'm posting here is I can't decide whether procrastination is the real addiction I have, or whether it's games. Certainly games seem to be the thing I turn to the second I am alone with free time, but if I left them out of my life would it be any better? Or would I just turn to another equally pointless hobby? Has anyone here experienced this and moved on? Or is it something I shouldn't worry about?

I hope everybody is doing ok with everything that is happening lately. Today I wanted to do a post about courage and how much it is needed when you embark on your journey to defeat addiction.

Courage is this special ability that you have within yourself to fight for something that you value above everything else in this world. Courage is what you see in the movies you watch, the books you read or the video games you play when the hero defeats the vilain at the end.

When I was 18 years old an odd friendship I had in high school with someone that saw me as that weird dude that hangs out with Christian rock band kids and someone I saw as someone with parents that weren?t strict like mine turned into an adult friendship and I was quickly introduced to my worst best friend for the next 15 years alcohol. My disease got worse over the years, turned into a cocaine habit followed by a binge on various psychedelics, one of which (psilocybin) had the accidental effect of temporarily shutting off my addictive desire for alcohol and coke and everything else for that matter. I experienced a strange sense of peace for the first time in my adult life for a short time, but I didn?t do anything to look at the underlying issues, I didn?t stop going to the same bars, or hanging out with the same people, and I did not change my life in any way except not drinking. So, obviously when the mushroom effects wore off, I immediately gave in to my first craving and was back where I was alcoholic wise within a week as if I had never put it down. I got fired from my job, kicked out of my apartment again and found myself homeless for the 2nd time in 2 years.i went on like this for a couple of months before realizing that after tasting sober life, I wanted it for real this time. I called an inpatient facility in a completely different city, I left my drinking friends behind for good, and most importantly,

I was willing to do whatever it took to get and stay clean from all addictive substances.

No matter what that meant, no matter how hard it was, no matter how much I had to change my life Or what amount of work I needed to put into it or how vulnerable or uncomfortable aspects of recovery made me, I knew I had to dive in 100% willing and ready to work. Because that?s what it takes. There is no silver bullet. No one thing that will keep you sober. It?s a dedication and a drive to doing everything in your power to stay clean and make a better life than you had when you were getting high/drunk. That?s all.

I feel like it?s gotten to be too big of a problem, and could really use some advice on how to kick it for good.

I don't know how to react to my bf hiding his substance abuse. I am 36f, bf is 41m.

We have been together 2.5yrs. We live together with his two kids who he has half time. When we met my bf was recently out of a long term relationship, and I knew he was struggling with depression. We took it slow. He was upfront about substance abuse issues he had in his past. My understanding was his use of hard drugs (cocaine, benzos, opioids) was in the past. I knew he drank alcohol heavily, but over our first year or so together he moderated his drinking, phasing out liquor and sticking to a few a few beers a night. It seemed like he was working on himself and making positive changes. We moved in together around the 1yr mark.

Since we moved in together I have occasionally noticed some odd behavior. Nothing extreme, but constricted pupils, lethargy, difficulty maintaining an erection. And I mostly chalked them up to stress since my bf has a full time job, takes care of his kids etc. But the last six months I have become increasingly suspicious. My bf had some financial issues (nothing catastrophic, but smallish amounts of money missing, short on rent that sort of thing), I noticed the constricted pupils more frequently... I grew up around addiction and I just had that feeling something was off. I know people struggling with addiction can be high functioning, and it got harder for me to ignore the things I was seeing.

So I snooped through an old cell phone (I know, I'm embarassed). I found out he was using heavily when we first met and had been struggling since to slow and stop his use. But also saw that he had been in regular contact with his dealer up until the present. I have since looked over our shared cell phone bill and see they regularly communicate despite my bf saying they are no longer friends. This weekend I noticed the signs I associate with potential use, saw he been texting his dealer, and asked my bf if there was anything, anything at all, going on with him. Anything I didn't know about. I did not get specific, and he denied anything was going on. This morning I looked in his pants pocket and found a baggie with a hollowed out pen and some white residue.

I love my bf. He is a kind, gentle person. He takes care with my feelings. I truly thought we were honest with each other. I can't get my mind around the fact that he hid this from me. He knows I grew up around drugs and addiction, and lost a parent to an overdose. The most generous interpretation I have is he didn't want to scare me off. I also know his use stems from his traumatic childhood (he experienced physical, sexual, and emotional abuse). And he might have been too deeply ashamed to tell me.

But all that being said I still don't know what to do. My bf is high functioning, and if I didn't grow up around drugs I may not have noticed. I do feel intense guilt for snooping, but also don't regret it. I felt like I was projecting my own trauma with substance abuse onto him, but it's clear now I'm not.

I know we need to talk about it...but what is the best way to start that conversation? What boundaries should I be prepared to draw? Should I consider leaving? This seems to be the common advice, but it would be so hard for me. I believe he is a wonderful person who struggles to cope. Should I ask that he get treatment? My fear is things will spiral for him. He has some level of control now, but we that always be the case? And I just don't know if I can get past the dishonesty. That is what hurts the most. I worry I will always feel like is lying to me.

Sorry if this isn't the best forum for this, but I've seen a really negative attitude towards people with addiction in relationship subreddits. I hope anyone here will have a more empathetic view.

I saw a future for myself. I actually felt like a person. I even became vegan lol

I want to quit. I honestly do. I feel like it's harder this time.

I just need some kind people ok the internet to tell me I can do it I guess lol. This group helped me one time. I'm hoping it can for a second time.

To my person: I?m M(29) and I was addicted to multiple substances 5 years ago. At that point I only smoked weed. Now I?m 6 month sober. I have a decent job where the boss gave me the opportunity to take over the company( it?s a little electric company he wants to retire bc of health issues). I have a very loving gf who helped me out of the Abyss of drug use.

I had to leave my ?friends? behind me bc every one of them are drug addicts. Now that I?m sober I also know that I never had friends in my life ( it all started when I was 14). I was fine with just having my gf around me the past 5 years. But since New Year?s Eve I started to think about how it would be to have a best friend or even a friend around me that is close, sharing thoughts or problems with or having a good time going out. I just don?t know how ?normal?people become friends?? As a drug addict it was pretty easy? ?oh you take the same Drug? Let?s hang out together?

I?d say the peak of my addiction was in the summer, but as of lately ( December to Jan) I?ve been high as much as I could/drunk. But today I almost made it a week which is big to me. Next time I?ll try a full week + couple days :)

Id been using cocaine everyday for 1 year. If i wasnt doing it id be thinking about it and how to get it asap and it was destroying me in a lot of spheres. Physically, psychologically, spiritually . I wish i could say im over it but the sample size of being without it isnt too big. However, if my words can help someone get 1 week off whatever the fuck their hooked on itll be worth the post.

Im gonna enumerate some points.

You gotta commit to not using (i know the voice in the back is real but you gotta get the intention out loud if you have to and be incisive about the decision

You might have to hit rock bottom in order to get to the point you really decide to change. IT MIGHT BUT IT DOESNT HAVE TO.

Write it down. All the feelings and things this substance does to you. All the pros and cons. You will see there are no pros. How its just fucking up your life in exchange of nothing. 15 minutes of euphoria that you can get doing anything pleasurable which takes me to number 4.

Change your habits. Triggers can get you falling right back into it, so change habits and know why you are doing so. Go for a run, drink a lot of water, take a shower, read a book, go to work, start a project. Occupy your mind.

The first days are the most difficult. It gets easier, the bad withdrawals get softer.

Remember why you are changing your life. Cuz yoy love yourself man! You dont deserve having ur life, friens, family, jobs being taken away from you over this shit. Remember the ppl who make it dont give a fuck about you!!! If youre dead or alive dont mean shit to them. I guess ur better alive tho, living like a zombie and consuming their substance getting addicted more and more.

Practice a connection with the divine. Im serious !!! Whether its yoga, shamanism, catcholicism, evangelism. Doesnt matter! Have faith in something. Find yourself. Purify your house. Clean it up. Clean yourself up. Breathe the air. Love yourself.

Write down everyday what you are grateful for. Seriously, do it!!! Your family? Your dog? Friends? Write it down. Be grateful. Open your heart. Wish the best for yourself. YOU CAN DO IT. I CAN DO IT. WE CAN DO IT.

I wish everyone power of will, strength and determination. It may not look or feel like it but we're in this together. A lot of ppl have conquered it, and we can do it. Live a better life. Enjoy the simple things and most importantly FEEL INNER PEACE. These are my opinions tho!!! I dont want anyone to think im trying to shove my truth in anyones face. I hope it helps. GOD LOVES YOU!!!!

I?ve been getting really into reading books around addiction, I?ve made a little compilation of a few of my favourites I?ve recently finished.

If anyone could leave recommendations on more, that would be great!

Undoing Drugs - Maia Szalavitz

I can?t even praise this book enough on how insightful it is about harm reduction. It covers the history of harm reduction (1970?s-Present) and all the corruption, stigma, pain and suffering that happened in between. It highlights major players in the harm reduction scene and the historical moments that brought us closer to a better future for addicts. It highlights the major issues still present, and provides examples of other options in harm reduction that have been used worldwide.

I detoxed for the 3rd God damn time at the beginning of the month. Im an opiate user. But the last 7 years or so I've been on methadone. Something happened and I blamed the methadone and stopped taking it and started using again because the detox off of methadone is a fucking bitch.

I held my shit together for months. No one knew. Then my job shut down for a week. No money no drugs. So after being so sick for 2 days, I went to detox on Jan 3rd. Barely remember the first few days and when I got out I didn't feel right. I chocked that up to being dehydrated and hungry and slept deprived. I hadn't really eaten or drank since the day I got sick or slept. Ended up leaving detox on the 6th day and trying to do the right thing I went to rehab.

I lasted 3 full days before I left. First rehab and it was an awful one. But at that point I hadn't slept more than an hour or two a night since I first got sick. Still hadn't eaten since before detox and I had to force my self to drink at least a little. I had no motivation. So I started telling myself was that I just needed sleep. So thats why I went home. Because my mental clock is off and I sleep better during the day, always have.

Took some doing but I convinced my mom to let me leave. I went home and actually managed to eat and grab a few hours of sleep. Next day I still felt awful. Figured thats to be expected. My sleep debt is enormous and I know there's an adjustment period before sleep would become regular. But I thought the emptiness I was feeling, the fog would have at least lifted a little...

So I did a little research into how long it takes for dopamine to start being released naturally again in addicts. Yeah, wish I hadn't done that. 3 months is the low mark. For people using a long time could be over a year.

I'm a tough mother fucker. Been through a lot. Too much for someone my age. But this. This indifference to everything that I've been feeling? This is unlike anything I've ever gone through. I've been on the couch since I got home. If my mom didn't feed me I wouldn't feed myself. Im still barely sleeping at all and if I'm being painfully honest I haven't even fucking showered since I got home. Theres no motivation to do anything. Nothing.

Everytime you feed yourself, drink something, anything to take care of yourself, your brain gives you a hit of dopamine to reinforce the behavior. Did you know that?? Because i didn't. I would have done things differently. Get back on methadone at least and get off it slowly I guess. Idk, but it sure as fuck wouldn't have been this. But my mom doesn't want me on methadone again. Truly I don't want to be on anything, but I'm so done but this emptiness. I can't live like this.

My body no longer knows how to function without some type of opiate. Thats fucking terrible. Sitting my heart rate is at 90. Can't sleep. And all sort of other shitty shit. But you know what, I can deal with my body freaking out. Like I said, I'm tough. But when there's no longer any care about or for anything how do you deal with that. My mind, the very essence of me is just broken.

Theres no way to understand the feeling if you've never felt it. Its not like depression where there's a dull ache. The pain beneath the surface that robs you of your interests and motivation, your will for life. I've been depressed most of my life and fuck if I don't want it back. Just to feel something. Anything. Pain. Anger. Sorrow. Despair even. I would kill to feel any one of those. Good feelings are just a dream now.

Worst part is, I have a paycheck waiting for me at my last job and some tips. I don't want to use but I don't know how much longer I can deal with this empty in the center of my chest. I just want to feel something. I've always been so passionate and energetic, I want to feel like myself. Not a stranger in my body.

I know this is super fucking long, and if you stuck around I appreciate it.

But I'm looking for some one that has been through what I'm going through now. I need to know that it's possible to get through this. Because, I don't know how much more of this I got in me. I just need encouragement and understanding from someone that understands really how awful this is.

I'm trying to get help before it gets to where i have to have it throughout the day. Today is my first day trying to get an appointment with a specialist. Im 28 and I want my life back. Anything would be appreciated.

I believe that mental addictions (such as gambling, food, sugar, sex, or cannabis dependence) are still chemically addictive like other drugs. Here's my 2 cents: I have a lot of experience with cannabis use, as it took up a large portion of my life (I'll share my story on that in another post later this week). While being milder and less harmful, Cannabis/THC trains the brain to withhold the release of natural pleasure chemicals, like Dopamine, and only release them once you give in to temptation. Same thing can happen with food, sugar, or sex.

If you feed the addiction long enough, it takes more effort to retrain the brain to no longer be dependent on external stimuli to trigger production or release of neurochemicals.

I am a 58yo woman happily married for 20 years (2nd marriage for both) to my 59 yo husband. He is the greatest person I?ve known. My problem is that I?m a recovering alcoholic, pill popper. Now I do need medication to control my anxiety and panic attacks. I have a prescription for .05mgs of klonopin that may be taken as needed but only 3times a day max. Now I know that I cannot have these pills in this amount around me because I know I will take them even if I think I may get anxiety later on. That?s the truth and the addict in me. So I had a long talk with my husband and explained my situation as best I could to someone who never even thinks of pills. I ask him to please give me 3 pills in the morning. Just leave them on bathroom counter or in a small bottle. It helps me maintain and really think before I take a pill. I asked him to please keep them away someplace, anywhere ? seriously don?t want to see the bottle because I get triggered. Hard to explain this to someone that doesn?t have an addicts brain. But I?ve tried over and over. The ?problem? is that he just never remembers. Never? I have to remind him almost daily. I feel guilty even asking him to do this for me but it?s obvious that I need his help. I find myself getting really frustrated s as d it?s not even his fault. It?s my problem that I?m asking him to help me with. It?s at the point that I?m about ready to order s locked pill dispenser but they are pricey. Serious question: Am I expecting too much from him? I feel terrible laying this on him but I definitely need his help. Anyone out here have any advice or a solution?

In the present time, I have seen and experienced many forms of addiction from gambling, drugs, food, alcohol and many others. Different people fall in different traps but there must be a pattern of how we come to be dependent on a substance or a type of behaviour. People experience everything in a different way, but our addictions are not so different after all. There must be a pattern in our decisions which triggers this dependence on certain behaviour. Many manage to overcome and break free from their rabbit hole, but many others struggle with themselves and only hope for a way out. I want to hear your story and were you any different?

So I?ve always been interested in drugs, since I was a kid. I didn?t realize I had anxiety until I had my first Xanax at 20 years old. I thought everybody felt nervous like that all the time. Deadass.

So specifically, the drugs that turned me to rehab were cocaine and benzos (Xanax, flualprazolam, klonopin, Valium, clonazolam, etc.) I finished the inpatient program after 4 months. I was extremely confident that I never needed drugs again.

Originally I?m from California but my parents moved to Texas when I was 19 and living on my own.

After rehab, I moved to Texas (I was 24 now) and well wouldn?t you know it, your addiction follows you anywhere. I found coworkers and met friends with coke plugs, xans, acid, etc. I moved to get away from the people, places, and things that spiraled me into a full blown addict, owing drug dealers money and stealing from my own family. But I was back at it and HARD. I convinced my best friend to leave CA to TX and get an apartment with me and my bf. He is a polydrug user as well (my bf doesn?t do drugs or drink at all), and it didn?t take long to get into the spiral of doing coke everyday, having to take a shitload of Xanax to counteract the negative effects of the coke. On and on it went. Well things went south with my best friend and we moved out of the apartment after 5 months and my best friend couldn?t afford it on his own, so we were left to our own devices. My bf (who I met in TX) had his mom and sister living in Colorado and they offered to help us get on our feet. So we did. After my year in Texas on a drug induced binge, me and my bf move to Colorado. Well one of my friends from TX was also from CO and had just moved back. As a polydrug user herself, I found plugs for coke again and started buying RC benzos even more. Then I got a klonopin script on top of all that. So my benzo use has been off the fuckin rails. I?ve wrecked 3 cars, cussed out my mom, and went on road trips I don?t even remember.

I began attending NA (virtual thanks to COVID) meetings and kept that up for a couple months. All it took was one bad day and I was asking my friend for coke. She had multiple plugs and it was just like the old times again. Back on coke binges and just being a total bitch when I didn?t have it. Then comes the benzos (which I take daily), because even when I?m not using that day, my anxiety is THAT high. I?m halfway through my month?s RX of klonopin and I got it a week ago. Now I?ve turned to alcohol, often mixing it with benzos. I know the risks but I do it anyways. I can?t stand the feeling of being sober and I don?t know why. When I got out of rehab I stayed clean another 4 months, 8 months total. But here I am, stuck in the spiral no matter what state I move to. It?s the addict brain I guess.

My question is, where do I move on from here? I have a job I love and don?t want to (although I may need it) go to an inpatient rehab again. Not to mention my insurance in this state is more expensive and I?m not even sure how it would work here. I just need help. A shoulder to cry on and wonder why a smart girl who got into her dream college and dropped out chose drugs and stealing over the bright future I could have had. Now I?m 26.

I need help and I finally realize that (AGAIN) now. Oh and I got to experience alcohol withdrawals for the first time. Used a shitload of benzos and that was barely enough to feel better. Wasn?t until I drank some whiskey that I felt better. I?m broken and slipping backwards. At a super fast pace.

Self pity does lead to relapse. The whole 'poor me, poor me, pour me another drink' has always rung true for me. I was having a shit time drinking, then got sober and realized I felt even more shitty underneath. All kinds of depressing shit started too happen, I was feeling the "something bad is going to happen" feeling all day. We shouldn't forget we're in control of how we feel.

There will be another moment when I think: not this, not now, another fucking thing on the pile of shit I have to deal with, fuck it. But fuck "fuck it". I have to be aware of the "fuck it" moment, and take a step back, since every other step after that would otherwise be self destructive. "WHEN will I catch a break? When is my reward? Why do other people have it so much better, even those who are suffering seem to be doing ok? Plus, the whole world is collapsing!

Today my doctor officially switched me to 2mg strips!! And I feel great! I don't feel the addicts grasping fear of losing out on some potential high. I can't believe it. I never could have imagined myself here just a year ago.

I gave up these badboys when I was 30, in that I gave up smoking it all day, every day. But then I was drinking and eating (like a monster) then too - and just very unaware of any of my coping mechanisms, (pre autism & adhd diagnosis & general self discovery on the next level...)

I've curbed it all now, finally, at 33, except I had a bit of an emotional meltdown in November and smoked for a good six weeks, came off after Christmas, then my grandma immediately went into hospital and then died at the end of January, so I kinda just carried on smoking almost constantly and HEAVILY for three months.

I've been smoking these ungodly amounts and have known it was going to really sling me into a bad, bad place when i stopped... and we are here now. I'm done again because I can't do it in moderation, my lungs are absolutely fried before I even manage to get a hit after say the fourth or fifth joint. Its expensive and unsustainable and doesn't align well with my current spiritual values. Weed blew me wide open and changed so much, but that use became abuse and I just needed to move forward.

Anyway what i am really here for is possibly, hopefully reassurance from people who understand.... Addiction is just the hardest thing I've ever, ever, ever dealt with. Trauma as a child, then the double whammy of autism ritual joy and then adhd emotional management and all that comes with that... it makes things utterly impossible to do like a normal person. I don't have any addicty friends these days and am really struggling to speak to someone who gets it....

So now of course I'm totally raw and feeling everything. I slept for 2 days straight, and coming out of that I managed to have a great session on the drums and a big walk, however, I'm on day 3 now I think and I just feel absolutely, absolutely terrible, mentally and emotionally?

I'm functioning and flowing through life like a melancholy ghost but irritable beyond belief, of course all the usual silliness of withdrawal, but then there's the existential dread that is just making me feel like a perpetually short fusing circuit that's about to be sucked into a black hole.

It's clawing away at me through my upper back, I feel panicky, just, this complete existential, awful, terrible, just terrible, terrible feeling....

Smoking will make it all go away but then it will come back worse, so I can't possibly prolong the inevitable any longer...

Please god, is there anyone out there with some grounding, earthing, reassuring, understanding, motivating words to help me through this. I can't remember how long this lasts... am I going to be okay??

Does anyone have any funny, reassuring, kind stories or words or even a lecture...?

We are looking for adults, 18 years and old to complete a survey on New Psychoactive Substances (NPS) experiences. The survey is being administered by R.A. Malatest, a private research company in Victoria, BC on behalf of Health Canada and the data will be used to better understand NPS use in Canada. If you?ve used NPS in the past 12 months in Canada, you can tell us about your experience by completing our short online survey.

The survey is open to anyone (residents and non-residents, 18 years and older) as long as the NPS experience took place in Canada within the past 12 months.

What addiction really is
Addiction is a constant reminder, after months or even decades continuing. Addiction is awesome, it feels good but you just don?t know it yet: the consequences that is. Addiction is harmful, you know it isn?t right. But it feels good, and you?re confident. Addiction is unhealthy, if you keep going, but you know it if you keep at it, it?s something that ruined people?s futures. Addiction is realized, you realize you?re addicted , but it feels good so you don?t really care. Addiction is now part of your life, being addicted has become a part of your personality.

Just wanted to give my own experience of being addicted, don?t ask what. Just stay away from addiction.

I?ll drive him somewhere if he needs a ride (his vehicle got taken cause he didn?t pay it off), I?ll go to family gatherings with him, but I haven?t asked him to hang out like we used to in over a year. About 3 years ago, he dumped his ex (not my mom). She was a heavy meth user (only towards the end of their relationship as far as I know) but it was only clear to me she was on meth after they broke up. I would see her around town skinnier than me (I?m 100lbs) and she used to be fairly big (no larger than 300lbs) when dating my dad. I also know the effects of meth, as I?ve had other family members who use it, and it was clear she was addicted. The meth was a major reason for the break up, and only a very small amount was because of the way she treated me and my sister. She was so rude to us, she would call us names and act as if the house was hers (it was 100% in my dads name and she didn?t make enough money to pay rent). I?m not going to go into detail about her, because this post is about my dad. About 2 years ago it started getting bad. My dad would do ride share late at night and starting stealing my sisters car. Then about a year and a half ago, me and my sister found a crack pipe in her car (she does NOT use, there is no way it was hers or a friends). Ever since then he?s been on a downward spiral. First, he lost his 13 year old dogs this summer. Then, at the end of the summer, my sisters puppy got parvovirus and passed away (not even a year old). He was really close to her dog and was devastated when he passed away. Then, his truck got repo-ed from the bank from not paying for it for over 2 years! This next issue is why I?m making this post. 3 days ago, I gave him a ride to my sisters car to boost it so he can go out for the night. (It?s -40c here) He told my sister he would be back by noon the next day, so I thought nothing of it. He was very talkative when he was in my car, but I didn?t think he was high. After he boosts my sisters car, he leaves. Not to be heard of since 4 hours ago. My whole family was trying to get a hold of him, he made my sister late to work, and he didn?t give a shit. He was active on Facebook throughout the 3 days and no one got a reply. The only reason we know where he is is because he was caught by my stepdad rummaging through my sisters car a few blocks away from his current place. (I think it?s pretty clear why he was parking far away; he knew we were looking for him and didn?t want us to see her car at his house) He was high as a kite and said he wanted to ?gamble? one last time before New Years. Now I just don?t know what to do. No 18 year old should have to watch their dad go thru all this shit. I have seen friends go thru this stuff and once I can?t handle it I?ve cut them off but I don?t know if I can do that to my own dad. I haven?t talked to him yet, planning to on New Year?s Eve. If anyone has any advice as to what to do in this situation please comment. Anything would help.

I knew my older brother (24) has experimented with drugs when we were younger, but didn?t know how bad it was until about a year ago. He had a lot of medical issues, and had surgery on his arm for nerve pain. He has troubles sleeping and has a week immune system. On these meds post surgery, he was still taking Xanax and who knows what else. I found him overdosing at his computer with powder on his desk and a cut up straw. The ambulance came, and he was in the hospital for a few days.

My parents and i cleaned out his room because we were so worried after and found tons of things that we weren?t expecting: tons of bags, cut up straws, dmt residue, kratom, Xanax, heroin residue, etc.

It happened a second time at his girlfriends house a month later. She didn?t know about the severity of his drug use, she couldn?t bear to see him that way so they broke up, and she ended up moving into the apartment they signed a lease for, without him.

He agreed to see a psychologist, but he only went once and never returned. He seemed to be doing better, he was going to the gym a bit, spending quality time with my parents and myself (even though we weren?t close growing up). However we recently noticed a large number of new bags that had heroin in them popping up, he has very little money considering he makes a decent living and has little expenses, and today he said he has been having trouble sleeping and having very vivid nightmares that he was in jail. Hours after waking, he was still convinced that what had happened in his nightmares was real. He was convinced he was in jail despite the fact he hasn?t actually left the house in 3 days.

I guess what I?m saying is my parents and i are extremely worried. We love him very much, but how can we help? My parents find it difficult because they can?t exactly control him given that he?s 24, and they can?t monitor what he does. They don?t want to kick him out because that will make things worse. I understand that many people going through this sort of thing are not comfortable talking about it. I just want him to be better but don?t know how to help more than telling him i love him regularly and that I?m here for him anytime. I reached out to a psychologist specialized in addiction to talk about this stuff, but figured i might get some good advice here.

This is my second time posting. I really need advice on how to help my niece, but honestly just the opportunity to unpack all my emotions here would be very helpful. I want to take a short trip back to four months ago. It was then my niece was fired from her management position, according to her account, for no reasons whatsoever. I was told there was a problem with time sheets. This never made any sense to me.It is a small town, so my nephew happened to stop in the business and said, "hey whatever happened to the old manager she seemed nice?" The new manager said the old manager was caught doing dope in the bathroom. When my nephew told me the information made total sense. It was after she was fired that she went back to work at an old job where her coworkers all abused opiates and after the crackdown they can't get scripts, so my fear is they're dabbling with the devil in heroin.

Over the months that followed after the firing I saw my niece drift further away from my nephew the two of them were always so close. This also meant she didn't visit me any longer and I knew it was a bad sign. I guess I blame myself a bit for not stepping up as soon as she was fired and pressing her for answers.My past experience tells me any pressing her will result in her taking this "whoa is me I'm suffering attitude" and "I'm not using drugs I'm just tired." So tired that she started dipping out asleep during the meal. I looked down the table with her mouth wide open full of food looking like an OD about to happen and I am helpless. The family that hosted dinner was scared for her and the next thing you know she is jumping in a car and driving away. Family pleaded with her not to drive, but she left intoxicated on drugs.

Cut to the next day. My nephew and me encourage my niece to come over and hangout. Niece declines and says she "feels so bad" she can't see anyone right now. We both assure her there is no need to feel bed just come hangout. My nephew and me were both trying to keep the dialogue open. My niece refused to come and her texts were long drawn out excuses why her being fucked up isn't her fault. My nephew makes the bold choice to talk to my brother and tell him, "Can't you see that your daughter is fucked up on drugs?" My brother in complete denial says, "she said she was tired and I believer he. Back story is that my brothers wife is also dabbling with the pain pills and like mother like daughter (I feel such anger) I guess he doesn't see either of them fucked up.

The last family event before Thanksgiving (anniversary of my mother's passing away) it was my brothers wife that couldn't stand up to say a prayer making a scene on the beach while we tried to say a prayer. It was horrible, but I had empathy that she needed help. The problem is nobody is getting help. I wake up and want to text my niece, "Are you safe?" I really don't know what to do anymore because my niece doesn't want help. My niece wants to wallow in "how her life was hard" and "she doesn't get any love from her parents" and "she is constantly wronged in jobs and that's why she isn't working. The girl is about two days away from being homeless. Here is where the advice kicks in...

What do I do when she's homeless and I don't feel safe having her in my home where there is Rx? She has stolen medications multiple times - the last years ago because I set her up and counted the pills before she came over. I am afraid for her that she'll overdose. I'm afraid I can't help her because she doesn't want help because she doesn't have a problem. She clearly has a problem dipping out in front of the whole family after she claimed to have looked forward to seeing family so much.

Did she show up fucked up as a way of shouting for help? My nephew asked about her getting help and she says "she'll go see a doctor." That doesn't work she needs to go into rehab because she has supposedly quit so many times - each time in rehab she found a way to sign herself out.

I pray this fits into the topic - I need to help my niece but she doesn't want the help, so what can you do? I took the previous advice and talked to family about the addiction and some are in denial and others just pulled back not knowing what to do. What can we possibly do?

I was always interested in playing video games like any male kid I guess but the thing that started my path towards addiction was the first computer(well second since the first one was one of those old big slowpokes that we played solitaire and minsweeper on).
I was in 7th or 8th grade of elementary and it was supposed to be for school but it was prob the least about that - it was 60% gaming,20% porn,15% youtube/social media and that last 5% was for school.
My parents never really placed a limit on how much I(we - my brother and sisters) could be on it and so of course we were on it the whole day.
It was fun,thinking about those endless hours of playing cod2 or counterstrike source brings back fond memories(online friends,guilds etc).
As I grew older I feel like gaming became boring and porn and youtube gained in % a lot.
I did have a phase where I was trying to learn programming,animation,3D modeling and drawing.(4 years)
Over the years as I have choosen being home on the computer I have basically obliterated my chance of having friends,like real life friends that you hang out with,play games,talk with etc. and cuz of that I felt that removing this toxic thing aka stopping from being online was me getting rid of this one last thing that kept me happy/distracted from how goalless my life is.
I currently dont work as a programmer or 3D modeler but thats the only thing in life that ever drew me in but I feel like shutting down the computer,phone(my phone is basically a distraction for me at work when there is little work and I use it to read reddit and for gatcha games(gambling ones that I am caring less and less while I used to spend real money on them in the past)) and doing some excercise,meet some people and just shut off the online world.
I feel like that now,but tomorrow I'll probably be back at the "safe place" or when life challenges me in some way be it at work,awkward social situation...
I am about to have 28 years and my life is basically a whole lot of nothing and I dont think I have still accepted/learned to work for something for years to achieve it.
I used to work for 4 years and I had a low income and there was just one goal that I set and just with basic caluclations it wasnt achieavable.
I would have had to not spend any of the money for 4 years just to buy a crappy second hand car that would prob break in 5 years.
Cant even imagine how hard it would have been if I couldnt use the car of my mother.
Sry about a long post,it could have been longer if I added more details but this should suffice to depict the state of my mind.

I am a student who is doing a research project on Opioid Addiction. The purpose of this research is to find an answer to the research question ?What factors can make a person more vulnerable to developing an opioid addiction?? This survey only takes less than 5 minutes and is open for people of all ages, and regions. The only requirement is to be a person who is currently dealing with an opioid addiction, or had previously had an opioid addiction. This survey is 100% anonymous and confidential. However, a sign in to an email account is required and is only in order to prevent multiple responses from the same person. This email address is not revealed to the creator (me). In regards to the survey, all answers will only be analyzed by the creator (me) and data will be represented in graphs, charts, and statistics.

I saw my niece yesterday. She was supposed to come over for a visit at 11. I didn't see her, so I sent her a text saying are you still coming at 11. In return I got a phone call with my niece all stressed out saying, "did I tell you I would do something for you?" I said, "no, you said you wanted to visit and would be here at 11." I was just following up with her. During the call I noticed an elevated tone of voice, fast speaking but with this groggy sound to her voice. I told her it is no problem if you're not coming I just wanted to know. I also said, "you sound completely wiped out why don't you get some rest and visit when you feel better?" My niece said, "No, I have to come on the island anyway."I said, "oh, are you still getting working down the south end of town?" My niece said no, she wasn't working and offered no reason for coming on the island. This is relevant because I live on a barrier island where tourism is king and places aren't open now. There is nothing to come to this time of year.Honestly, it made no difference if she came over or not. Anyway, about three hours later I get a phone call. It is my niece and she' around the corner if I want to hangout. I say yes because I'm home and she gets here. She is loud shouting about how she loves my couch and chairs. She is overly animated about a used couch and a chair. She tells me she is not going to work anymore for the next six montys and is going on unemployment, but in the same sentence she tells me her unemployment is screwed up and had been for six months. My niece never did anything to secure unemployment payments. My niece has already opened a claim six months ago and never responded to their request for additional information and that is how things got screwed up. In her mind, she was wronged by the system. I talked to her carefully and told her, "no, I don't think they tried to screw you. I think you had to call in and report that you had hours of work and no longer wanted unemployment. She is spacey and never did it and now is pulling this, "whoa this is happening to me." Now, to get to the gut wrenching part. While she was here I noticed the way she was talking, I could see she was moving really fast. At the same time we were sitting on the couch I actually saw my niece dose off to sleep. Now, I understand not getting a good night sleep, but this was different. My niece was dipping out just like I remember from before when she used. Another weird thing I shared with my nephew is how my niece kind of disappeared about six months ago. We used to hangout regularly and all of a sudden she didn't come on weekends and she stopped replying to texts and phone calls. This isn't normal behavior and when my nephew and I saw her we both agreed she was clearly using again.

I am afraid my niece was high on drugs (opiates) and the reasons why she was on the island was supposedly to give someone a ride to the market to get gerbil food. My niece would have driven more than an hour just to take her friend to get gerbil food. No fucking way - I call bullshit. I think my niece was on the island on the other end of town to score drugs. She stopped working and now she's saying she didn't get unemployment and whoaa is her what is she going to do.

I don't know what to do. I want to call my niece out and say "you're high on pills," but last time I called her out she cursed me out, told me she wasn't high (a complete lie) followed up with horrible things being said about me and she would never talk to me again for accusing her. My niece did talk to me again when she needed something. And, I have no problem with her ups and downs about how she feels about me. The thing is I was accurate she was using drugs.

I can't help to think she came on this island to score drugs because she has old friends that were users. A few years ago I noticed the same pattern with her keeping in touch and hanging out with old "friends" she used to use with. I think the person she saw today is her supplier.

I currently don't take any mood stabilizers for my bipolar disorder and have struggled for a very long time with a drug addiction also. Somehow I was always able to fly under the radar with it at the workplace and still be high almost 100% of the time. Drug abuse inevitably always got to the point though where it didn't even matter anymore if I got high from it or not, I just needed it to function that day and to feel "normal". All the years of thinking I had it under control did finally hit the fan at my last job. I got fired for the first time in my life and my addiction was the reason. I've been constantly beating myself up over it every day that I've spent jobless ever since. I can't even get myself to look for another job anymore either because the shame runs so deep for me having to explain now in an interview why I got fired from my last job and that alone keeps me from moving forward with my life. I really want to be honest about it so they don't end up finding out anyways with a routine call to my last place of employment or something. It needed to happen though or I never would of quit using. I am clean now for 4 months so I'd put much emphasis on that part and hope the honesty and taking accountability for making bad choices would stand out to the interviewer way more than just them judging me and immediately placing me with the negative stigma drug addicts get stuck with instead. I'm starting to feel like I don't deserve a second chance at all now because even I see myself being a drug addict as worthless and flawed, though I'm clean and should be proud of it. I'd love to change the perspective I have of myself but drugs took all the good qualities away and replaced them with just the toxic ones instead. So, here I am, trying to clear away the wreckage and pollution I fed to my mind, body and spirit all those years while also relearning what life is supposed to feel like for the average sober person too.

With my honest assessment, I'd have to say that I became an entertainment, self-improvement information and video gaming addict. I say this with an intent to convey the fact that these things in themselves may not be addictions, but currently, I'm doing them way too much and I don't experience pleasure from doing/achieving the regular stuff or any desire/drive/motivation to go through the hard things in order to achieve something or to be of service.
Like... I know many things that I could do in order to improve my life and possibly others' too, but I simply can't force myself to do it quite often. A few months ago I've had a great drive to grind one video game, I've done it for a couple of months almost non stop. I felt great, I was excited, happy to do it and it was my goal. Now, I don't have even a few % of that drive and motivation to do the same thing. It became literally boring and... I don't know, dull maybe?

While I'm not depressed in the mood sense (Feeling sad), but I'm lacking any drive, ambition and desire to do anything meaningful (even though I intellectualy understand and know those things). It's just like I have to force myself constantly to do anything (except for watching Netflix, porn, eating very tasty food and playing video games --- switching these activities constantly because one of them could get boring pretty quickly).

My main point of the post is as follows: how do I create the reset? The doctors and scientists that I've referred to in the title have mentioned in their interview that abstaining from the activity could greatly help in resetting the dopamine (which in turns raises the pleasure levels of more normal/less stimulating things/activities and possibly raises the desire/motivation to do things).
Which behaviours would fall under stimulating activities and which not? I think of reading books, learning new skills, being socially active (hanging out with other people and getting to know new people). Which of those are actually the ones that would add to the problem?

I'm thinking of travelling to another city to my grandma's place for a month at least, spend time with her without brining my smartphone or computers (thus, I'd have no way of constantly sitting on them and doing those things). Also, I'm a bit of a food junkie, but I know of ways to prevent myself from doing those things (giving away my wallet and finances to grandma while I'm there).



In summary, I think of meditation, physical exercise of various ways, reading books, spending time with grandmother and conversating with her, eating regular food and drinking water/teas, going for walks by the sea and in the nature, maybe even riding a bicycle. Do any of these activities stimulate enough for the dopamine reset period to be less effective?

my name is Johnny, i am a recovering addict who has a little over 3 years clean. I see a lot of post with people asking how to stop using. You got to really wanna stop using for that to happen, you have to work really hard on your recovery. Meetings, sponsorship, depending on the severity of your addiction you may need to take the time and go to treatment. I promise you this when you make that choice to get clean your life will become your dreams. I did over 7 years in prison due to my addiction, i lost family, i lost friends, addiction takes everything. Instead of trading everything for 1 thing that makes your miserable, trade that one thing for everything that way you can have the life you dreamed of. God Bless you all and remember recovery takes time. But as time goes on it does get easier that i promise !

I?ve come to realize I need to have at least one addiction in my daily life. First, it was smoking when I was in college. Then I quit, but started drinking alcohol instead. I then went to see a psychiatrist to quit drinking and started taking Lexapro for anxiety. Now I?ve stopped taking Lexapro too, but am back to smoking.

I realized I crave a way to ?end the day? with something that?s supposed to be relaxing and stress-relieving, like alcohol, cigarettes or anti-depressants. I usually spend the whole day just feeling anxious about every little thing, then at night I would crave that stress-relief substance, whatever substance.

I?ve tried meditating, practice mindfulness, breathing exercises; I have so many hobbies like painting and interior design. None of that helps me satisfy the cravings, like they're not strong enough serotonin boosters. I don't want to be a slave to these destructive habits, and I don't want to keep fighting one addiction after another for my whole life. I've made an appointment to go back on Lexapro. Anti-depressants might not be the best solution, but I figured it's better than alcohol or nicotine.

Therapy is very expensive where I live; a one-hour session is more expensive than a month's worth of alcohol and nicotine. Maybe in the future I will see a therapist when I'm more financially capable, but for now, does anybody have any advice on ways to stop craving bad habits as a way to relief stress?

22 (f) sober since May 2021? it might be extremely overwhelming for anyone to watch especially if you?re overcoming addictions.. however, i think this show inspires intellectual and necessary dialogue about addiction, love, being a young adult in an unforgiving world. At first just a little when I was bored or stressed. Then just like the drug itself I did it more and more and have triggered myself into a crazy addict state of mind.

I can?t hardly think about anything else. My brain is hatching schemes on how I could obtain the drugs. I?m wishing they would just fall into my lap somehow. I plan on using the free counseling offered by my college but guess I?m writing cuz I don?t want to feel alone in this fight anymore and this is much less anxiety inducing than disappointing the people I care about most. I have a question about a situation that blurs the line of addiction. My partner (female) drinks at least 3-4 drinks (and more) every day and has for the last few years. That is considered heavy drinking by the CDC and various medical sources, and is linked to various negative health outcomes. She sometimes drinks enough to throw up. We are mid-30's, not the age where you don't know your tolerance, however she is not a sloppy drunk on these puke nights to where it's obvious it was a mistake. She rationalizes it as a related anxiety adrenaline response that causes nausea unrelated to alcohol (e.g. "the alcohol triggered my panic attack").

The reason I'm asking for help is to figure out if I should say something or not. Most alcohol addiction/abuse sources mention treating alcohol as an addiction when it starts to interfere in work or relationships. My partner has begun to have what I call "second order" effects, such as depression, sleep issues, mental clarity issues, and physical changes (whereas first order effects are obvious intoxication, missing work, etc referred to in other sources as interfering with work or relationships). However, the link between second order effects and alcohol is not obvious -- i.e. she could be drinking to cope with another issue causing the depression and sleeplessness (a la self-medication). My partner has also recently shown other addictive tendencies within the past 5 years (obesity and online shopping).

She has had alcohol abuse and cancer in her family history, which is part of the reason I worry about her classification as a heavy drinker in what appears to be a new normal and not a phase to deal with short-term stress.

So, my question to the sub is: am I right to worry about long-term effects and should I gently intervene? Or is it none of my business until she shows classic "first order" effects of alcohol interfering with life? Are there good sources for how to intervene in a preemptive health way, rather than the typical advice for how to intervene with a sloppy-drunk-obviously-alcoholic person?

The term ?Safety Behavior? is an all-encompassing recognition of the many ways that we manage difficult emotions. Whether positive or maladaptive, coping can take many different forms. The motivations behind our actions are important to take note of or else we may be perpetuating anxious responses.

There are 2 main types of safety behaviours (coping), one helpful, and the other lacks mindfulness. If you interested in deepening your knowledge of coping behaviours, take a look at todays short talk with The Detail.

My best friend has been addicted to drugs for about a year now. It got pretty severe after they suffered a really traumatic experience that almost killed them.
