I hated the way I was, it constantly left me in a dangerous state of mind and doing xanax made me forget more than half the things that happened. When they made their first attempt to get professional help, I promised myself and them that I would never do hard drugs again, especially while I'm with them (and I haven't) because I didn't want to be in a situation like that ever again and even though I knew they would've done it anyways, I didn't want to contribute to their addiction. They've been struggling with it ever since. Addiction is definitely and sadly something I've always grown up around and seen. My parent overdosed. My other abusive parent was addicted to hard drugs and is still an alcoholic as well as most of my family. And just last week, I lost one of my closest friends to an overdose, and I'm still mourning the death. Addiction is not a choice, i understand that. I struggle with my own addictions, but I'll ever understand not having the option to just quit an addiction that causes excruciating pain and some cases death or having to cope with an addiction for the rest of my life. I feel really selfish for even feeling this way, but its really hard to keep my feelings to myself and also try to be there for my friend. I'm scared every day that I'm going to lose them, that I will say something that will make things worse, or they will get really hurt by what I say. It hurt so much to sneak them drugs before I left the hospital, see them go to the funeral high and make jokes about drug overdose after my friend passed away, comotose on the couch when friends are over, and to be in dangerous and uncomfortable situations or have my feelings compromised for their comfort. Ive told them how I felt before, but I think it just made things worse. I know they can't help it and they're taking on such a burden of trying to get clean without any help and suffering from cptsd. I want to be here for them, the last thing I want to do is make them feel like a bad person, but I can't if I'm being put in these kinds of situations. I just don't know what to do or how to feel.

I got so much more than usual done today it almost feels like a distant memory. Usually my typical day consists of doing (maybe) one productive thing and I ride off those waves for the rest of the day. Today however it felt much easier to bring myself to do things. I woke up and just felt like doing some gardening and... I just did it.

I also went for a quick jog in the park and worked out with my skipping rope. I am sore all over and I know waking up tomorrow is going to be a chore itself????. Though I do feel better about myself for putting in the effort to develop a healthier lifestyle.

However, the lack of consumption is starting to have its effects. My now less than usual levels of serotonin are making me feel more emotional and there are some elements of old feelings and personality fragments being brought up. I am choosing to take this as my subconscious coming to terms with these things and that this is a necessary path to the ultimate goal.

I am exhausted n

Today was surprisingly much better than yesterday, I had many temptations all throughout the day but somehow found it much easier to let go of them and to control my mind. I feel so much more in power in my own body (if that makes sense). I absolutely enjoy this feeling and know now that this is what I need to do for myself. Many years from now I know that I will look back and appreciate my efforts that I put in now.

Due to my newly implemented rules I am slowly regaining my self respect and treating myself better. I make sure to put my phone far out of reach each night and read a couple pages of my book before I head to sleep. I now wake up much easier and feel more ready to take on the day. I am still nowhere near the level of cognitive activity I was at years before but this small but meaningful progress means a lot to me.

Today was pretty fun. I woke up late and browsed the internet for a bit. I finally restarted working out which felt great after my short break. Had a quick dental check-up for the upkeep of my braces and then I got started on this gardening project that I had delayed for a while.

I am typing this at 3 am so let's just ignore the possible incoherence haha! But nevertheless, I feel more at peace with myself from just 3 days and don't feel so exhausted. I am slowly beginning to realise the self destructive patterns I had put in motion for myself which is important and needs to be addressed. That's all for the day and thanks for being here!

I'm here because my wife has admitted to an addiction of drinking. There's a lot to it and I want to be succinct. This has come out over time (together 10 yrs), and I unwittingly contributed to it. I feel horrible about that, and didn't fully understand what was going on. While she isn't a full blown alcoholic in the sense that this is veering out of some semblance of control, there have been serious problems recently that have put the spotlight on this. I'm unable to conceptualize addiction or how to properly help. I personally hate the feeling of not having control on a personal level, and keep my alcohol consumption in check rather easily. My wife has also admitted, and I have realized, that she becomes a completely different person that is merely a mimic of her sober self when she drinks.

Important points:

We are health oriented in general (clean diet, regular fitness, etc).

Wine is the vice, but there's no such thing as "just one drink" if there is an option for more (for her).

We both went dry in prep for a race that lasted 2 months, and it was great. Since then we have trickled back into occasional (and very limited) drinking; for reference we will share 1 bottle of wine, or have up to 2 drinks on a planned outing, with multiple dry days in between.

No alcohol just sitting on the shelf in our home.



In the interest of healthy support, I am looking for ways that I can contribute to, and maintain a positive space for my wife to overcome this challenge. I need to better understand the mindset of an addict without prying (my wife gets very defensive if I pointedly bring certain things up). I feel like this is manageable without external intervention beyond myself. I want to do this without explicitly highlighting her addiction in the negative connotations that seems to be the norm. Any resources or advice with this approach would be of great help.

Words of encouragement to those who battle addiction head on like a warrior. I proudly and openly talk about my past and don't mind sharing my own experiences with anybody who listens. I refuse to let my scars define my entire life or define who I am. We all deserve the love and support without feeling ashamed or beaten down for mistakes that so many of us think we have to wear the reputation of being a drug addict and seem to be labeled to society through an entire life time and recovery is all we think about. Its okay to educate, talk and spread awareness but don't be at to rediscover yourself and create your own self. You have gone through it all and you have fought to create an entire life for yourself.

Yes an addict is seen ad viewed for the things they do amd the reputathon can be hard to get past for us all. Don't forget to not hold onto the guilt and punish yourself for bad choices you hace made. We are humans, we were destined to make mistakes, feel unworthy or even like we deserve being viewed as lesser people to society.

I know for fact that most of us have suffered through rejection and definitely haven't won a popularity contest in this world. The pressure can be hard on us to be normal or liked...we are brave, compassionate, misunderstood and sensitive about our feel.

You can become an entire different person - don't carry any label but you can love and embrace the new person you've become. You re worthy and its up to addicts to support one another.

I understand her concerns as he is still very weak and frail from cancer treatments. She thinks that the best would be a place that uses medication on an outpatient basis to treat the pill addiction first but he can continue to drink. I told her I don?t think you are technically supposed to drink on any addiction medication. Let me begin this by saying- this is not meant to judge anyone. To say anyone is wrong. Or to put anyone down based on their choices and their reasons for doing things. I truly mean that. Simply to put something that's been on my heart out there hoping it may touch someone. Cuz if it does, a life may be saved. To anyone who is looking at going into rehab, not because you really want to get clean, but simply as a way to get your parents, the courts, or whoever off of your back- please take the ones who truly are trying to get better into consideration. Because as any adict knows- when your ready to ask for help, there is a very good chance your lucky your still alive, and feel that if you don't get help soon, your going to die. A lot of people don't know how frustrating the process for someone on their own to get themselves into a rehab can be. Now I think it should take work. This is the first step back to being the responsible adult you lost sight of due to your addiction. And being an adult requires work. But calling morning noon and night praying everytime you ask "do you have a bed" the Answer will finally today be yes. And crushed each time it's not. You start out strong. "I can do this. I'm stronger than this. I'm better than this. I'm worth fighting for." Are all things you tell yourself. But with each passing day, and the withdrawals kicking in more and more. Along with the mental part of withdrawals. Which can honestly be worse than the physical- your feeling good enough and worthy fade back to where you were in that addiction. You begin to start feeling like " what was I thinking? I'm not worth them giving me a chance to get clean. I'm not strong enough to fight this. I can't do this. I'm wasting mine and those trying to help mes time. Cuz I'm too far gone. And so often after days and days of calling praying someone has a bed for you, people simply give up. And it's heartbreaking. And so often those beds aren't open because people are trying to fake good long enough to get back into someone's good graces, with no intention from the beginning to actually get clean and stay clean. Now I know sometimes something sparks inside the ones who go in doing just that, and they do get and stay clean. And that's amazing. What I'm getting at, if you don't plan on taking it serious. And appreciating the new lease on life your being given the opportunity to have- please, I'm begging you- don't take up a spot that someone truly needs and is praying for. Please.

My name is Robert, and I am an alcoholic. Furthermore, I am a person who is recovered from countless addictions and behavioral challenges. I was like so many individuals who were lost and afraid that nothing would ever change. I remember feeling so isolated and alone as a child. I was so confused and scared that I would get lost in my tears. I remember lying in bed at night when I was five and six years old and wondering why it hurts so much being me.

As I grew older, the pain deepened. When your pain goes to the degree that my pain did, it sets up an interesting dynamic. We learn at an early age that we are just not comfortable in our skin. From the earliest of memories, I remember I wanted to be somebody else, doing something else, be somewhere else. I did not feel comfortable in my skin. I was never satisfied.

My family dynamic was that of an alcoholic father, a codependent mom, and I was the middle child of seven children. We grew up in a home that was always upside down, and trying to find my balance was impossible. I became the chameleon. I never knew what someone else wanted or how I could become what I had to become for others to accept me.

Maybe you can relate to these feelings that I had. By the time I was a teenager things became much worse. As a child, little is expected of you. As we grow, so do the expectations that others have for us. This was not only true in my family, my social circles, and even academically. Because I did not feel that I had value I did not believe I could produce anything of value. The hole gets deeper and deeper and deeper.

We end up in what I have heard termed ?the hole of no hope.? When I was 14 years old, I took my first drink because I could get away with it. I remember how it made me feel once the alcohol hit my system. I went from being nothing to almost. When you come from nothing, are convinced you are always going to be nothing, being an almost is the top of the world. Every subsequent drink I took was an attempt to recapture that feeling of being an almost.

When one is convinced they will never amount to anything, being an almost is everything. In the beginning, it seems harmless enough and the frequency was based on the amount of emotional pain that I was feeling. I found as I got older, and my social circle grew, and my family and educational expectations grew, my anxiety of not measuring up grew as well. As I was constantly being reminded, the feeling that I was nothing grew, and so my need to be an almost grew proportionately.

Since I could not become almost on my own, I had to find the opportunity and the alcohol to be fulfilled. This is where the cycle became dangerous. My reliance was not on me feeling good about who I was. It was based on a substance that I found myself increasingly needing in frequency and amount.

When I turned 16 years old, I realized my drinking was getting out of control and had become obvious to others. It became necessary for me to experiment with other substances that would enhance my sensation that alcohol alone could no longer produce. In the beginning, a joint here and a joint there was sufficient, but that would make me tired and lethargic, and I was not left with a very adequate means to concentrate in school.

Someone introduced me to methamphetamines, and this helped keep me up and active during the day. Now instead of just drinking, I was smoking marijuana and eating amphetamines. The challenge with that was not eating, and I found it increasingly more difficult to sleep. That is when I began to introduce barbiturates into the rotation. Barbiturates were a very curious drug; that they did what alcohol was doing, but did it without the hangover. This went on and on until I got to my senior year in high school and on my 18th birthday, I decided to drop out of school.

It was January 3rd, and I would graduate that May. Nevertheless, my drinking and using career was needing my attention. I found it more important and more necessary to drink and use than what I thought a high school education could bring me. As the years passed and my struggles became greater, there was not a relationship or an opportunity that I was not willing to set aside to drink and use.

By the time I was 27 years old, I had become chronic in my addiction. I had added compulsive gambling, overeating, pornography, and I started throwing up three to five times per day. I was at the end of my rope and I knew that if something did not change, I was going to die. I knew there were no more chances for me.

On February 9th of 1986, I entered treatment and admitted I was an alcoholic. I was introduced to Alcoholics Anonymous, Narcotics Anonymous, and other 12 step groups. I began my pursuit of recovery. I began going to meetings and meeting new people. I was enjoying what I was finding in the rooms of recovery. Nevertheless, I found it so difficult in being honest with others.

I was sincerely afraid that you would find out that I was nothing. I knew that if I spoke too much or became too honest, you would figure that out and I would be the first person in the history of a 12-step program that you would ask not to come back. I know that sounds laughable to some, but it was a real fear for me.

Once again, I knew that something had to change, or I was going to die. I knew honesty was the best path for me, yet being honest was almost as fearful as the death that was waiting for me. Sadly, that led to my relapse after 71 days of being sober.

Fortunately for me, I only found it necessary to drink for five days. I was trying to recapture that feeling of being an almost. At the end of those five days, I realized that the only place for me was back in the rooms of recovery. On April 25th of 1986, I walked back into the rooms of Alcoholics Anonymous and I have never left.

That means that as of April 25th of 2021, I am celebrating 35 years of personal recovery. Even more astounding than 35 years is that it translates into 12,784 consecutive days of saying yes to life and no to my addiction. The journey has been remarkable.

There have been some challenges along the way, but then again, life is filled with challenges. I will never forget what it was like being a newcomer. It was the most frightening thing that I had ever experienced and yet I could not leave because I knew that I would die.

I realized that the only way for me to stay clean and sober and to become happy, joyous, and free was to apply the plan of recovery to the best of my ability. I made it my passion to go to meetings, get and work with my sponsor and become acclimated to a power greater than myself. As I did those things and began incorporating the 12 steps into my personal life things began to change in ways that I could have only dreamed of.

I went from being a nothing and an occasional almost to somebody who had more hope than anyone I had ever met. I began to resemble the people that I had met in the rooms of recovery. I began living and sharing some of the stories that I had heard them share with me.

When I would hear them share those stories my heart began to dance and sing, and I wished that those things would happen to me. They have happened to me and so many more. I cannot imagine a life that does not include one day at a time (ODAAT) and living a plan of recovery. I can honestly tell you for nearly all my 35 years of personal recovery, I wake up every day with a sense of gratitude and peace in anticipation because of what I have been so freely given.

I meet many people who are struggling the way I had struggled. I speak with many individuals who are trying to find the magic that would take them from dying a lonely death to a life of personal fulfillment and that surpasses all understanding. This is what I have found in my recovery journey. I was so fortunate that I met so many amazing people along the way.

Every person of significance to me, (outside of one who died during a relapse) is either clean and sober today or has passed away in sobriety. When I mentioned these individuals, I am talking about people who are sober 37, 39, 41, and 44 years. My sponsor Jack passed away two years ago with 44 years of personal recovery. Individuals like Texas Mike, Pete the Greek, Russian Ted, and Doc Irv all passed away as recovered members of the 12 Step Program.

One of the most exciting things about the plan of recovery that I followed is that it is a complete blueprint. When followed, the likelihood of having all the things it promises is all but guaranteed. I don't mean to say that everyone who starts the program of Alcoholics Anonymous finishes or lives a sober life.

What I am saying is I have never known anyone to relapse when they followed the path. After my relapse back in 1986, I was face to face with how dangerous I was to myself. The prospect of another relapse scared me more than I had ever been scared. I asked my sponsor what I needed to do to never relapse again. The answer was simple. The answer is service.

When I decided to incorporate the plan of recovery into my life for the express purpose of becoming more equipped to help others it completely revolutionized my thinking. I was no longer about me. It was about ?we.? Developing this way of thinking was transformational for me.

A section in the Big Book of Alcoholics Anonymous talks about selfishness and self-centeredness being foundational to every problem I had ever had. Setting aside my ego is the best thing I could ever do.

Growing in sobriety has been the greatest journey one will ever take. That is exactly what recovery is. Recovery is a journey; it is not a destination. I am so glad that there is a finish line other than death.

My goal is to accomplish what my sponsor Jack Fisher accomplished. Jack sadly succumbed to cancer a little more than two years ago. At the time of his death, Jack had 44 years of continuous sobriety. As I chatted with him in his hospital room and knowing it would be the last time I was to see him alive, I asked him ?Jack, what do I tell them? What is your message you want me to share with others?? Jack looked at me with his cancer sunken eyes and said ?Bob, tell them it works.?

That simple phrase has resonated with me in different ways. The most important way it resonated with me is that it underscored the simplicity of what we're doing. There is no magic. There is no wondering if or how or when. The program of recovery works when you work it.

My message to you - and I want you to hear this loud and clear - is it works. I see so often people in social media bashing one recovery program or another.

Here's the deal, they all work. When you look at some of the programs within the monotheistic religions of the world and other secular programs, they work. There are far too many people who have been successful to suggest that they don't work. The common denominator of anything less than success is not the program, it is the person applying the program.

The opening paragraph in Chapter 5 of the Big Book of Alcoholics Anonymous reads ?rarely have we seen a person fail who has thoroughly followed our path. Those who do not recover are people who cannot or will not completely give themselves to this simple program.? End of the story. I am fully convinced that when we apply the 12 steps of Alcoholics Anonymous and the plan as laid out in the first 164 pages of recovery, our result will be permanent sobriety.

I also believe this to be true with the Muslim Faith, Judaism, LDS Recovery, Celebrate Recovery, the Buddhist Network, and the list goes on and on. If you are involved in any of these programs or find a program where it has been demonstrated that it has worked for countless others, then guess what, if it doesn't work it is you. Why not humble ourselves?

Why not be as honest as only a dying person can be honest? I love the simplicity of the program as it states all we need to be is honest, open-minded, and willing. If we are these three things daily, there is never any reason for us to go back out again. So many people go out and never come back.

I count myself so fortunate to be a person who relapsed, found the doors of recovery still open, and gave it another go. As I wrap up this message to you today, I want you to know how grateful I am to have been given the gift of recovery. When I consider myself to have been clean and sober for 3 1/2 decades I am beyond grateful. What is even more astounding is that today is day 12,784 consecutive days of saying yes to life and no to death.

The areas in my life that I have been given are beyond, but I believe I deserve it. I have a marriage of 32 years. My children that I abandoned at the height of my addiction have forgiven me and we have a loving and working relationship that is in a continual process of heightened healing.

I don't regret who I am. Matter of fact, I celebrate who I am. I am no longer a person who came from nothing and would remain a nothing. My goal is no longer to be almost. Today I am somebody filled with hope, potential, and a satisfying heart of helping others achieve what I have been able to achieve.

I hope you are one that I can pass this mantle onto as you are beginning or continuing your journey of recovery. I have been blessed, fortunate, and honored to go from broken to whole. I desire to teach and guide others to find their way.

There will come a time that I am as Jack was. I will be laying in a hospital bed getting close to my last breath and someone that I love and who loves me will ask me what my message is that they can pass on. My message to them will simply be ?it works.?

Holy crap this is hard. I'm 3 days "clean," today is day 4. If I get through today it'll be the longest streak I've had since I've started this journey. I use the word "clean" because I'm not addicted to a substance, I'm addicted to calling this hotline (it isn't a sex hotline, but I'm not ready to share what it is). Calling this hotline gave me hope and a sense of valiadtion (or even the hope for validation!). I'm also not having sex -this has also been a struggle. Typically I have sought validation through sex or attention from the opposite sex. Facing both of these is difficult, but I know necessary.

Fast forward years later, we got married and have a child. When i found out i was pregnant, i got sober off all substances immediately. He struggled. He would disappear for days on benders, but i was always here wanting him to come home. We fought but then again i was once him. I did coke daily, i drank like a fish. We were one in the same.

Things are different now. We have a child, i am a mother and she is my purpose and drive day to day. Somewhere along the line he started smoking crack daily. If he isnt high, hes asleep. If hes awake hes manic and paranoid or nasty. Cant hold a job, finances are on me. Taking care of our child is on me. Our home, our pets, i am now alone but living with an empty shell of a person. He Refuses rehab, quit IOP multiple times. What am i to do? Why cant he just stop like i did? Why am i the outlier of drug addiction that i turned the other cheek and never looked back on the life i lived?

Our marriage, our livelihood, our family is in jeopardy. Family doesnt understand, how could they? They dont know my history. They wouldnt understand.

Please reddit, help me make sense of this and help me find the answer of what i should do.

Fellow addict here. I?ve (18F) been smoking for years now and while I never really wanted to quit before, I?ve been practicing self-improvement lately and figured it would be best for me to do so in order to live a longer more fulfilling life. Not just for me, but for my loved ones as well.

Main downside is, a lot of my loved ones smoke as well. My older sister is the one that got me started, and me and my brother and best friend (who is also like a sister to me) have all smoked together since early high school. This includes cannabis and nicotine.

Thinking about it now, I can?t understand why we thought it was okay to start so young. We all had our issues, yes, and still do, but it should be a no-brainer that smoking does more damage than repair, right?

I worry sometimes that because I?ve integrated it into my life from such an early age, it will be nearly impossible to quit. Especially because they don?t even want to. The only one who really supports me is my boyfriend who I plan on moving away with soon.

I thought moving away and just getting far from it all for a while would help towards me quitting significantly, but lately I?m having doubts. Has anybody else on here quit both vaping and smoking weed before? The green isn?t as hard, but vaping seems nearly impossible as this point. I'm moving in with a friend for may 1st. She's been in AA and recovery for about a year and a half, during Christmas time she relapsed twice back to back and was back on the AA/NA bandwagon. So she's been 90 days clean now. I'm forever happy and proud of her. But I have some concerns.

I'm moving in in May, my parents will be helping out for her half of the rent till she moves in for July. Lately although I truly appreciate her honesty, a lot of things she's opened up about has given me some concerns. She's asked to not be on the lease for the first few months which is okay as she won't be living there. So I said we can put you on the lease when you move in. And she said yeah we can look back at it for when that time comes. She's opened up that she doesn't know if she can pay the damage deposit right off the hop because she can't afford it due to not having an income. So I said you'll have to speak to your parents about that because I can't cover that. And on top of all this stress and anxiety for her she's having bad withdrawals every other week.

I don't want to criticize how she's handling life right now. That's not my place and I understand that helping her for my benefit is not the way to go. But as much of a best friend she is I feel I still need to be realistic. I think living in a home together guaranteed with no alcohol or drugs around would be great for the both of us. But I need reassurance that she will pull her weight equally. And to atleast show that she's trying to better help her financial situation. This all being said my fear is that if she's already close to another relapse line, saying these things will push her over they edge. I need some advice to have these conversations because although I've gone through addiction myself, in my story it was a lot easier to pull myself out of it compared to. I don't get the full grasp internally but have seen it destroy others lives due to the thought of the bigger picture and responsibilities they need to take on.

I pray that others like me make it back to reality, and that anyone who comes across this compound turns the other way.

OK. So I've been going through some things here recently. I hope and pray that I am able to fully articulate my struggle and explain my reasoning behind everything going on and why I did what I felt best.

I'll start by saying I was 2 years sober when the pandemic started. Covid cost me 2 jobs, a house, and a relationship. I was starting to crack at the seams and on April 29th, it happened. Trump gave me my stimulus on the worst day of the year. I don't blame Trump, or the extra influx of money into my account. I blame myself and a lack of accountability. But I relapsed. I spent 3 weeks in hell and caught a case. I bonded out and got myself together.

However that did not last long, a few months later I relapsed again. Spent another few weeks in hell and got myself together before getting into trouble. All the while I wasn't really in contact with my sponsor or anyone from recovery.

But this time different, I decided to reach out. I decided to ask for help. And help is what I thought I got. I moved into sober living, was going to meetings and doing the steps all over again. Life was great! Or so it seemed.

Then I started to notice how judgemental a Nast majority of the recovery community in my city was. It was like being in catholic church again. Do this or goto hell. Do this or die. Do this and God hates you! So I chose to keep my head down and my circle small. But somehow the judgemental cesspool which is the indy recovery scene just seemed to seep its way in. The you're not part of the "cool" kids table really started to show thru. Everytime I reached out, everywhere I turned I saw fake hope and people lying. People judging and people ultimately hating on myself or others who seemed to be doing good.

Anyways fast forward a few months and I made the ultimate decision to remove myself entirely from the recovery community. It's not that I want to smoke dope. I don't. It's not that I want to be a waste of life and die a lonely man. I don't. But I don't want to surround myself with that hatred, the lack of real empathy for another's struggles. And the people who were "in crowders" or cool kids as I call them looking down on everyone and making me feel bad for anything.

I deleted 90%of my recovery related friends. Removed myself from all the local recovery groups on fb, and have basically isolated myself to a small group of family and friends. Am I setting myself up for a relapse? Have I done what I always do and convinced myself of lies? Or is it possible that I'm right and the recovery community not helping in ways I thought were "why we do it" the reasons for my relapses?

Again idk if I'm articulating my struggles or giving a fully accurate time line of events bc this is all off the top of my head. But any advice would be much appreciated! Much love and respect!

Over a year ago, I decided to stop taking amphetamines. I was really really bad into it for a good three years. A lot of people say you can?t be bad into amphetamines but I was super duper bad into it. It was ruining my life and ruining my body. It was something I stopped doing without any rehab or meetings. I stopped shortly after my father dying. I just started going to therapy and told my therapist I was an addict and I needed to stop and so I just stopped. But since then, I haven?t had much guidance otherwise. My therapist hasn?t been much help. I?ve stayed away from the drug itself, but I smoke weed periodically. Otherwise, I?m also a recovering alcoholic, and I take naltrexone to keep it that way. I haven?t drank in over a year, either. After coming off amphetamines I fell right into alcoholism. Which I never expected either.

But here?s my question: I ask myself sometimes, why did I get into amphetamines? What was it about that drug in particular? When I was on amphetamines I never had a drinking problem. I actually hated drinking.

Also, Why do I drink so much coffee everyday, now? Why do I smoke so much nicotine? And is it possible that these things are just as bad as the amphetamines?

Prior to the addiction, I was 17, and I had no prior substance abuse issues. And now I?m so reliant upon stimulants at the age of 24. And I want to drink every single day. My body literally craves alcohol.

What happened to me? Is there a reason my brain is so reliant upon stimulants? Is this part of being an addict? Will my brain always be addicted to stimulants or will it be better if I stop smoking nicotine and drinking caffeine? How does the brain of an addict work?

I?m really sorry if I sound ridiculous. I want to be more aware of myself. I just want to understand myself. And I don?t have much guidance right now. I feel like this is sort of the only place I can go with my questions. I really appreciate your time.

So this might be the wrong place, a bad question or even horribly stupid. I am 40m - frequent social drinker (1-2 times a weeks) and occasional social drug user (edibles, mushrooms seldom, and the occasional bump/party night aka coke). I imagine I?m not the only one, but COVID has changed things fairly drastically. I am immunodeficient so I have been self isolating since feb/March (almost a year holy crap). I have been diagnosed with anxiety and depression for about 4 years - which I am on meds (but have been struggling to take on a regular basis, I have no idea why...) I now realize before diagnosis I was self medicating just to be around people and ?drown my sorrows?. I have 4 people in my bubble that I see maybe once a month. None of these are meant to be excuses or looking for sympathy - I?m just trying to give a little back ground.

Recently my drug and alcohol use has increased significantly. I get high off edibles sometimes 3 times in a week. I drink to get drunk (I have no social life anymore) typically 3 times a week. And I now use - much more than before - coke every time I drink. Somethings all 3 in the same night. By myself. And each are being increased because I?m trying to escape that voice in my head, the depression, the anxiety, the loneliness. There?s usually at least a day in between these nights. During the hangover days I get down. To the point where I want to kill myself (lately getting worse). I self loath, and hide from the world. I don?t work my regular hours. (Lucky enough to be able to work from home - and always get my work done but often after hours). I tell myself I need to change. And I?m going to change. But then a day later - I catch up on work and feel better and then decide to have a drink and then I get high and the cycle repeats.

Does anyone have any advice on how to cut back? I want to be a casual drinker/user again. I know most people would say that there is no ?safe? amount of using. But I just want things to be back to how they were. (Covid is a long way from being over I understand). I don?t care to do drugs unless I am drinking. Never once even tried it. But I am I delusional to think that I can go back to being casual? Do I need to stop drinking and using? Is it bad that I don?t want to? Typically once or twice a year I will take a month or two off without any issue - to focus on health (get the ol ?beach bod? back) or if I have a large project for work. No major cravings per se - but I also isolate myself from the social situations that would involve drinks. I get fomo from it but no actual cravings for the booze or drugs.

I?m terrified of people finding out. I am scared of what I would do if they did. I would try rehab if I could do it without anyone knowing. But ultimately I have it in my head that I don?t want to fully stop. Most of my best memories are a result of drinks and using with friends and family (most don?t use - most don?t know I do either, I?m fairly aloof). My relationship with my Dad is largely based on our love for wine. (Wineries, tastings, sharing discoveries)

Has anyone been able to cut back? If so, Any tips? Or am I stupid and just need to cut all this crap for good?

I won?t be offended by any opinions or insights. This is a newly created account because - as I mentioned - I?m terrified of people finding out. And somehow still want to hide it from the random internet people who don?t even know me - it?s pathetic I know.

Thanks for reading if you made it this far. Even if you don?t have anything to say. Just typing this out is making me feel a bit better and thinking that someone may have read it.
